175954054,"I think there is a wide range of things that falls under traditional medicine. I tried nutrition, herbs and cupping (Chinese med). The herbs i tried were helpful, some of them, but they too had a lot of side effects. I felt like i nor my herbalist really knew what we were doing. So i decided to just solve my problems instead of suppress them. I only use saffron still, on rare occasions. It helps against anxiety and depression (shouldnt be combined with antidepressant). The cupping afaik just caused huge ugly circles on my back temporarily. I try to stay away from all the “spiritual” healing stuff because it doesnt fit my faith and it scares me. E.g. someone proposed i do a 3 week shamanistic ayahuasca healing against sz, but that seemed like a pretty risky undertaking. My mind is crazy enough without hallucinogens. 175954136,"Vegan chili: 1 can black beans (drained) 1 can kidney beans (drained) 1 can corn (drained) 1 can seasoned chili beans (undrained) 1 32 oz can tomato sauce taco seasoning to taste chili powder to taste Just put everything in a big pot, bring to a boil, then reduce heat to low and simmer uncovered until the thickness is what you like. Serve with crackers or rolls. Serves 4 vegan coconut curry: 1 lb bag frozen vegetable blend (i use one with mushrooms, peppers, onions, and baby corn, but it tastes good with any veggies) (fresh vegetables can be used, but that makes it more expensive) 1 32 oz can coconut milk (full fat tastes 1000% better) 1 tsp ginger 1 tbsp yellow curry powder (or to taste) cayenne pepper to taste (i do 10 shakes) 1/4 c dried coconut flakes (optional) Dump it all in a pot, bring to a boil, then reduce heat to medium for 15 minutes or until all vegetables are tender. Serve over rice. Serves 4. Fancy home fries: 1 potato 1 bell pepper 1 onion 8 oz mushrooms vegetable oil garlic salt Di
ce all vegetables. Preheat pan with oil on medium-high or high. Toss in one piece of vegetable. When it starts bubbling, toss in rest of vegetables, stir around to coat in oil, then fry until crispy on all sides. Season with garlic salt. Serves 3 as a side, or 1 as a full meal. Vegan smoothie 1/2 cup frozen fruit (whatever you want, honestly) 1/2 cup loosely packed spinach leaves (optional: replace with more frozen fruit) 1 banana (optional: replace with more frozen fruit) 1/2 cup non-dairy yogurt (optional: replace with more frozen fruit) Almond milk (or whatever preferred non-dairy milk or juice) Put fruits and veggies in a blender. Add milk or juice to cover veggies. Blend until smooth. Serves 1. Vegan masaman curry: 1 sweet potato 1 lb bag frozen vegetable blend 1 lb bag frozen green vegetable (broccoli or green beans are my favorite) 1 4 oz can masaman curry paste (can find on Amazon or in an Asian food market) 2 32 oz cans coconut milk 1/2 cup peanuts, crushed (optional) Dice sweet potato (I leave the s
kin on for extra flavor). Dump all ingredients except peanuts into a pot. Bring to boil and leave on high until potatoes are tender all the way through. Serve over rice, and garnish bowls with crushed peanuts. Serves 8. Black bean tacos: 2 cans black beans, drained 1 16 oz can diced tomatoes 1 bell pepper 1 onion 8 oz mushrooms (optional) 3 cloves garlic (can use powdered instead) vegetable oil taco seasoning to taste taco shells Dice vegetables. caramelize in pan with oil. Add garlic, sauté until fragrant. Add black beans, taco seasoning, and diced tomatoes. Reduce heat to medium-low and simmer, stirring occasionally, until liquid is boiled off. Serve in taco shells with favorite taco fixings… Serves 4."

175954153,"Doc told me yesterday to move from 25mg Zoloft to 50mg, and might have to then move higher. But try 50mg. I told him I had side effects at 25mg and was afraid of more side effects (insomnia and very jittery) at increased dose. So he gave me Klonopin and said take that at the beginning, while getting used to the SSRI. Anyone else do that? Seems like a good idea. I do not want a benzo addiction, but the doc said small dose for a short period, while getting used to the SSRI, will not come close to causing addiction. But it will enable me to sleep and reduce the (very uncomfortable) morning jitters."

174340838,"It’s not normal to have no money. But how long has it been since you were diagnosed with schizophrenia? After I was diagnosed I was jobless for 3-6 months. I had one temporary stint as an accounts assistant which I took just to put something on my CV. In that time I was on something called jobseekers, which worked out to be about 200 every month; this i had for about three months. You are absolutely right to feel trapped. Your parents may not understand just how big of a deal these conditions are and are still adapting. Mine were. They expected me to be able to have a full time job just because my CV from before diagnosis was good for my age. A year maybe two later, my parents are realising that my health will stop me being able to hold down a full time job typically. Even though my health has massively improved; they are seeing how it really effects me and realising what it can actually do. I feel for you. It’s not easy finding work without a car. A lot of employment requires travel. However o
n a positive you can drive, so you do have the skill. I would say try to make yourself happy. Keep listening to music and using Twitter as you say you have done and you will see things will change. Nothing ever stays the same imo. My recovery has all been down to three things. Music, twitter and walking. And I was regularly told I was making an incredible recovery. It can happen for you too. If the SSI thing works out. Just make yourself happy with it. It’s not going to be much, but it should let you go to a coffee shop. or to use a bus to go to interviews. Put your goal of getting a job and being happy first at all times. You deserve your own sense of identity and security which is not tied up to just what others have to feel and think of you. Unfortunately when you are trapped financially it becomes even harder to see yourself as your own person with own personality. It robs you of your living. In society where survival is based on money and not self sufficiency."
175954155,Christmas Music on Air 1
175954156,It’s a weird thing that although the drugs do their thing…ie receptor occupancy quickly and in the first 24 hours it can take a while to get results. Usually your looking at a time frame of 4-6 weeks for decent gains but it’s probably also dependent on you coming out of psychosis or depression. Hang in there. You’d expect some gains after a month but it’s a slow process but it is worth it if your getting it right.

174340844,"I can’t remember the exact costs of my medicines, but a box of 30 capsules of aripiprazole 10 mg costs around to R$ 350. It’s around to U$ 85. Good psychiatrists charge around to R$ 350 too (U$ 85). Good psychologists charge around to R$ 200 for each session (U$ 50 each session). I would say you would have a cost of around R$ 1850 (U$ 447) a month with mental health here in Brazil (if we consider buying two boxes of antipsychotics, monthly psychiatrist and 4 sessions with a psychologist). The problem here is that our wage is very low. A regular job with no degree requirement pays just around to R$ 1200 (U$ 290). But if you have an engineering degree, you may earn R$ 4000 (U$ 1000). _USER_ID_: fortunately, I use just half a box of aripiprazole a month, consult with my psychiatrist each 2 months and I’m not going to therapy, so I have a cost of just R$ 350 a month with mental health (U$ 85)."

175954198,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov Going Against the Grains: Gluten-Free Diets in Patients Without Celiac Disease-Worthwhile or Not? BA _PERSON_, PHR Green and B _PERSON_, Digestive diseases and sciences , May 2019 17 While the gluten-free diet (GFD) is the only known effective therapy for celiac disease, in recent years it has become increasingly popular in the USA and worldwide, with many believing it to be more ""healthful"" and others claiming that it has beneficial effects for health conditions, many extraintestinal, other than celiac disease. This review examines the evidence for use of the GFD in patients without celiac disease who self-report intestinal and/or extraintestinal symptoms (non-celiac gluten sensitivity), as well as for enhancement of athletic performance and treatment of autism, rheumatoid arthritis, and psychiatric disorders. Overall, the evidence for use of GFDs in conditions other than celiac disease is poor. Though non-celiac gluten sensitivity may ultimately emerge as a biomarker-defined co
ndition, a large proportion of patients with apparent non-celiac gluten sensitivity have, after careful investigation, an alternative diagnosis. In light of this, and coupled with the potential physical and psychological harms associated with the avoidance of gluten, initiating a GFD should not be encouraged for people who have these other conditions or are seeking physical/athletic enhancement."

175954234,"I’m not really an expert on this, but I do know that adrenaline (aka. epinephrine) comes from noradrenaline, which comes from dopamine, which comes from L-dopa, which comes from tyrosine. Part of the tyrosine comes from phenylalanine. Tyrosine and phenylalanine are amino acids that come from diet and/or supplements (proteins). Some herbs also contain L-dopa, at least mucuna pruriens does. Yes, cortisol is catabolic. Adrenaline is actually good for the muscles because it increases blood flow to them. Some people use adrenergic beta2-agonists such as clenbuterol for anabolic effects. -_NAME_."

175954425,"I’ve struggled with violent thoughts/urges for as long as I can remember. Believe I was suspended for a good amount of time for that. I was hospitalized late last year for homicidal thoughts. I checked myself in, because it had gotten to the point if I didnt I was dead set on doing it, and knew exactly how/whom it would be. Those extreme urges have passed, but I still get the fleeting urges I’ve had since childhood. Have always wanted to discuss this in therapy, but am scared of being hospitalized indefinitely. 174340892,"ncbi.nlm.nih.gov Facial Emotion Recognition and Persecutory Ideation in Paranoid Schizophrenia. _PERSON_, _PERSON_, _PERSON_ and _PERSON_, Psychological reports , May 2019 15 The recognition of facial signals has a crucial role in social interaction. It is well known that people suffering from paranoid schizophrenia have problems in the social domain, predominantly related to misinterpreting the intentions, emotions, and actions of others. The aim of this study was to examine whether there are differences in facial emotion recognition between people with paranoid schizophrenia and healthy controls. In addition, we examined the correlation between facial emotion recognition and the expression of persecutory ideation in people suffering from paranoid schizophrenia. The study involved 60 participants, 30 of whom suffered from paranoid schizophrenia and 30 healthy controls, equalized by gender, age, and education. The following instruments were used: Japanese and Caucasian Facial Expressions of Emotion 
and Neutral Faces and the Persecutory Ideation Questionnaire. Compared with the controls, people suffering from paranoid schizophrenia were significantly less accurate in recognizing the following emotions: surprise, contempt, sadness, disgust, and emotionally neutral faces. Since the attribution of emotions to emotionally neutral faces is an important finding that could be linked with the social (dis)functionality of people suffering from paranoid schizophrenia, we analyzed and compared the wrong answers given by the two groups and found some differences between them. The results show that persecutory ideation has a statistically significant negative correlation with the successful recognition of emotionally neutral faces. All of the findings lead to the conclusion that paranoid schizophrenia, and within it the existence of persecutory ideation, leads to problems in recognizing the basic facial signals that form the foundation of everyday social interaction."
175954426,"I see my pdoc in-person on Thursday. Will be nice to actually see her again. I think I'm doing pretty well overall. I mean, no voices, no mania or depression anymore since being on Trilafon. Some paranoia and anxiety and panic attacks but I've been coping with that through meditation, my hobbies, prn medication and distractions plus using coping thoughts/statements. 175954457,"There's a few different ways I've enjoyed using this website. 1) As a Journal - This is a great place to write out your mental issues either for just yourself or to be shared with one of its communities. Sometimes it just helps to get your concerns expressed into a jumble of words so your mind can move along to something less troubling. 2) Asking for help - Post anything your heart desires.. questions, advice, your therapy advice for the week.. and others will chime in as best they can. 3) Helping others - Resolve problems you didn't even realize you had by using what you've learned to assist someone else with their questions that resonate well with you. It's sort of collaborative problem solving and thinking through related issues in a healthy way can better prepare you for that scenario if it ever happens to you in the future. ... and so on. There's many different parts to the website so keep coming back if something new crops up in your life. Each with their own subtle tips and tricks to a bette
r way of dealing with each type of issue. Cheers,"

175954466,"In my two years of being on 3 mg of risperidone (the only AP I’ve been on besides the geodon I was given in the hospital during the psychotic break that started it all) it has caused me agitation at times and has contributed to significant weight gain. I do recommend those two problems over full-blown psychosis, of course. I really hope you can get on a med that helps you without side effects that are detrimental to your life, preferably without having to try out too many. It’s definitely possible."

175954475,"HI _PERSON_, My sober date is 6/23/2010, I have a sponsor and I have sponsored women. I previously worked as a Peer Engagement Specialist in the emergency dept (_NAME_). of my state's biggest hospital. I currently work as a Certified Peer Specialist for my state, working with clients who will eventually transition out of a State Psychiatric facility into the public with various levels of ongoing support. When I first got sober 9+ years ago, albeit long for this alcoholic but a short time for most, I remember taking a fellow AA member to _NAME_. His treatment was at best, fair. I saw the looks on the staff's faces as they came in to do what they had to do and could easily tell that they would have rather have been anywhere else. As a person who worked the steps I took it as a learning opportunity to humble myself to see the pain that some people carry regarding addicts. To see how it manifests in their behaviors. I wasn't happy about their treatment but I understood it. Even an alcoholic can get fru
strated at another alcoholic/addict when they don't seem to be ""getting it"". My time in the _NAME_ was a little different - 8 years later, the staff was somewhat softer to patients with SUD. I loved my time there because I got to be a part of the solution, helping addicts AND staff understand the helplessness and fear of addiction and sobriety. What I learned in the _NAME_ is that ALWAYS trauma goes hand-in-hand with addiction. It's very hard to behave in a way that is opposite of what your body is craving like air. Add to that a flooding back of all the feelings that initially disappeared when you were using. Many addicts would not even identify as having past trauma, to some degree neither did I but having some sober days under my belt and not giving up at just ""not drinking"" I was able to see the pain from the past that led me so easily to my addiction. There is a _USER_ID_, I believe, also combined with trauma, to a large degree. We, people with SUD, remind people of the traumas they experienced and t
hey see the alcohol or the drug and not the hurt that began the cycle of hiding real hurt. My frustration came when those that did not have the understanding because they were not addicts wanted to treat the SUD and not the trauma. I always told myself that I didn't get sober to be unhappy so I sallied forth but many people have no CLUE where to start. Life is harder as an addict but life FEELS harder without it and without a plan for learning how to overcome trauma."

174340908,"Hey all, So I was noticing lately that it required more labor for me to walk, I then began to get curious about antipsychotics and muscle weakness and it appears it can be a side effect. I haven’t been as physically capable as I was before antipsychotics but I guess it just took me 3 years to actually find out that is what it is. Back to the topic, I used to be pretty good at guitar but since going on meds I have had difficulty playing well and haven’t been doing it because it just isn’t the same. I think the increased difficulty in physically playing is part of it but I also don’t have the concentration due to schizophrenia giving me a more blank mind and also making it very hard to get in the zone musically. I can’t keep track of bars of music that I have played and can’t improvise or feel music the way I used to. Things are very different and it has made me pretty much give up on playing guitar or bass. So for me, guitar playing is very very diminished to the point that I don’t enj
oy it. I have just bought a digital piano/keyboard and am trying to substitute it as a hobby but am having the same issues of concentration and focus, it is more forgiving how I am playing it along to beats though, I can sort of get different grooves and patterns to go along with the beats but I still can’t keep track of what bar I am on.If anyone has similar issues I recommend playing keyboard along to beats, if nothing else . Music will always be probably my biggest hobby but it just isn’t the same, listening to music isn’t the same either but I can’t change how stuff is now I guess. Anyone else had some hobby affected by schizophrenia and/or meds?"

175954538,"When I am not doing well, particularly when I was off meds, ignoring the voices could be very very difficult and at times felt impossible, they were just so loud and clear in my head. And they’d say such inflammatory things. However on meds they are fairly easy to ignore. I don’t get them often and when I do they are typically “far away” or “muffled”. For me it is much better to ignore my voices and not get into it with them. It only ends up with me being upset and usually abused."

175954541,"_AT_MENTION_ you keep opening old threads. Please refer to our zombie threads rule. Typically, we like to leave inactive threads alone and just start a new thread instead. This is different than how some forums are run, but we do it this way because it frequently upsets users to have old topics revived when they are no longer relevant. It can also be frustrating to the person who revived the thread when they don’t get a reply, because the original poster is no longer active or no longer finds the topic relevant. Feel free to start a new thread on this topic. Thanks, Volunteer Moderator _AT_MENTION_"

174340925,"I’m 31. I was put on disability when I was 19 and started getting paranoid and depressed and had to drop out of school and couldn’t keep a job. It got a lot worse in my 20’s but now I’ve been pretty stable for 4 years. Just not able to function in the world enough to get a job or go back to school. Yet, I hope. I am so sad all the time, I often feel like I’m going to cry and sometimes do. My anxiety is too high to take walks in my nice safe neighborhood. I used to be able to. I just started going in the backyard most days to get some time outdoors. I check my room often, especially under my bed, in case there is a person hiding under there. Sometimes even if I go downstairs for a moment and come right back upstairs. As if someone (or someones) have been waiting for their chance to hide under my bed. It’s so embarrassing and no one except my therapist. I mentioned it to her once and we talked about it for a few minutes. But it really bothers me and I would be really embarrassed if anyone 
knew. Like, that’s too classic ‘crazy.’ And there is a moment between thinking of checking and actually checking where I am terrified. And just assuming that someone who intends to harm me is hiding under my bed and steeling myself to look anyway. It is a really stressful moment that I have anywhere from 3-10? times per day and I could live without that. I worry on a daily basis about the possibility that someone may be monitoring my computer or phone use, or watching me or recording me with the cameras on them. I’m a disaster. I’ve almost all the medications, really. Some with really worrying and unmanageable side affects. And without the medication I do take I’m much, much worse, because I’m in some kind of actual fantasyland version of my life and manic at the same time. I have a lot of PTSD stuff from highly manic/psychotic episodes and the many hospitalizations that followed. If someone were in the exact same position as me, if someone else had written this post, I would feel extreme compas
sion for them, and hope that they get the help they need and not think badly of them at all. I am a kind person. But I hate myself. I’m just kind of horrified at how my life turned out. I want to learn to like myself sometimes. Feeling the way I do about myself and this constant worry about safety and strangers is too heavy on me. My memory is terrible now and it takes me longer to read books and I’m usually too stressed out to draw or sew or do anything I’m actually good at. I’ve read a little bit about Acceptance and Commitment Therapy, but I have had so much therapy, and been CBT’d with no results. I want to volunteer at the library or a friendly safe soup kitchen I can even walk to, but my anxiety about people other than my family is too high. What should I do? `Do I keep trying medications? There are basically only two left because I really don’t want to try them for various side effect reasons, Depakote and Clozapine. Have you gotten to a more okay place than this? If not, how are you dealin
g with it?"

174340934,"Well, in the US at least, no positive symptoms means you don’t have schizophrenia. But it’s the psychosis that destroys grey matter, not negative symptoms. However, just because someone only displays negative symptoms at the time of diagnosis doesn’t mean that they’ll never develop positive symptoms. People diagnosed with schizophrenia simplex are also put on antipsychotics for that very reason. Just because psychotic symptoms are not observed doesn’t mean they aren’t there, no matter how mild they may be. I didn’t dismiss or downplay anything. I never even suggested that other illnesses and disabilities are less serious or severe. I said that autism, even severe autism, doesn’t destroy grey matter, which it doesn’t, therefore the two can’t be compared in this sense."

175954622,"I’m a 19 year old female who just started college for the first time this September. Now I’ll admit, I have felt easily overwhelmed by minor inconveniences & would needlessly worry about nothing 24/7 for a few years now, but I didn’t notice these problems until now because they weren’t interfering with daily life in the past. I straight up get TRIGGERED when someone mentions anything about school. I don’t like talking about my success and failures. I get so worked up over homework that I don’t do it (my procrastinating has reached its all time worst). I can relax but I will feel guilty about treating myself with TLC. Surprisingly, I don’t lose sleep over my stress and I have never experienced any sort of panic attack before. My mind’s always racing but you can’t tell from looking at me. I have a very hard time remembering and following through with simple directions. My family will often tell me to get a grip and stop acting _USER_ID_; like I know they mean well, but damn! I feel 
like I was born stupid. I don’t know what’s wrong with me. 174340940,"I believe in gradual weight loss. Can’t find any evidence for it, but there’s lots of evidence that rapid weight loss usually leads to putting it all back on and some. That’s been my experience too when I have been psychotic and refusing to eat. I avoid “diets” and only make changes I can see myself sticking with for the rest of my life. So I’ve just gradually cut down my eating in a way that I think I can sustain for the rest of my life. I’ve been doing it for 4 years and in that time I’ve lost 16kg (35 pounds). That included putting on 7kg giving up smoking and getting it off again. I know that’s slow, but hey if I hadn’t done it I probably would have put on 16kg, so really I’ve lost 32kg. I’m now out of the morbid obese category and just obese, which makes me happy. I’ve had to struggle with hunger from the amisulparide. If I eat to my appetite I’m putting on weight. So I tried to stick to around 1800 cal a day - I just counted occasionaly, saw how hungry I was and tr
ied to be roughly that hungry most days. Now I’ve changed to Abilify I can eat that without feeling hungry, so I find it easy to maintain weight or lose a little compared to before. Since I’ve added exercise, I haven’t lost much on the scales, but I’ve gone down a dress size. I weigh most days, and my weight fluctuates like the stock market, but keeping it in an app means you can see the long term trend."
175954639,Perhaps to you but to others you may be hitting certain flags. Psychiatry really is an art especially when it comes to meds and time constraints. It’s not unusual to think your sane around here when your out with the fairies. Believing in things that aren’t real to most is pretty well a delusion is it not? Yeah you can argue semantics but I’d suspect it boils down to medication. You come unstuck off medication then it’s a moot point anyways. Most folks around here need meds for life in our current medical tech.

175954646,"Citymouse , what are you own answers to those questions? For me: I definitely care about things, but I can't tell whether my internal experience of caring is the same as other peoples. Certainly there are lots of times other people seem to be feeling a much wider range of more intensive emotions than I feel. I care a lot about truth. It makes me angry when people don't care what is and isn't true, or when they conceal information because it is easier than being honest. I care a lot about people in a collective sense. I care about things being fair. I have strong left-leaning political opinions. I have very little interest in most people. Very few people are reliably interesting enough to be worth the effort it takes to engage with them. I don't understand why I am expected to care about Person X just because they are related to person Y who is a friend of the person I'm currently talking to. Even if Person X was in a car crash, why should I care? I already know that car crashes happen to people. It 
isn't information. It isn't something I'm able to do something about. I'd much rather have a conversation about how to prevent car crashes generally than hear how this one has personally affected someone I don't know. There are a small number of people that I care a lot about. I want them to like me, and if they don't, even temporarily, I find that quite difficult. The number of people this applies to is much smaller than the number of people I am socially supposed to care a lot about. Even with them, I'm still not sure I feel as strongly as most people do. Either that, or people exaggerate a lot, constantly, about how they feel. I'm not sure I've ever wanted to hug someone. I've learned the behaviour, but it took a lot of practice. I don't know if I care about myself. I'm not sure what that means. I care about achieving things, particularly my academic writing. I don't enjoy getting physically hurt. I get annoyed at myself - does that count?"
175954647,"Okay, so I left work at 6am this morning, like i do every morning, and I went to go shop for groceries at the store. I'm looking all about, and I don't buy much. I buy a few gallons of water for the birds and the lizard. They can't have tap water. I saw a post about bar soap being better than body wash, and like a heathen, I hissed at the bar soap and foamed at the mouth while quickly grabbing my body wash. I'm good on shampoo though. I use girly girl shampoo because I like smelling pretty. So that was the first aisle. The next aisle I went to was the cereal aisle. I like cereal, but I don't like the price of cereal. I go immediately to the discount section they have at the end of each aisle, for the products in that aisle. I found a few things. A box of Sour Patch Kids cereal, and I love Sour Patch Kids candy. The cereal tastes exactly like it. Thank god I only paid 76 cents for it, because two bites in, the bowl and the box went in the trash. There's no need a cereal to be sour. The other cereal 
I got were pop tart cereal. Strawberry, Cookie and Cream, and Cinnamon brown whatever. I tried the cookie and cream one and it was delicious. I imagine the other two are too, but that's for another time. I got some eggs and also made egg salad. I'll take a couple sandwiches with me to work each night until I run out. A nice, quick lunch, more time to enjoy a book on my phone through the Kindle app. Yes yes. It's just before 7:30am here. The birds will be waking soon. I got them some new perches to stand on, made of hard wood and concrete. These are to trim their nails so neither I nor the vet have to do so. It happens naturally. Yes yes. I got some more green tea. I've been wanting to try _NAME_ Grey for a while, but again, I got _PERSON_ Green tea. I don't drink it very often, usually on a day off. It relaxes me. My primary care doctor is all, ""that's got caffeine in it!"" and I'm all, ""whoa, dude, no way!"" It's why I only drink it during a day off though. I guess I could start drinking it at work. Maybe 
I'll try that tonight. Yes yes. I went to the CD section to laugh. It's a smaller than small section, like, maybe ten CD's to choose from. I listen to vinyl or I stream music off my phone, but if they had a good CD, I wouldn't have been opposed to buying it. They didn't though. It was the first time since, like, 1999 that I saw a Backstreet Boys CD though. I scowled at the sight of it, but I walked away and went into the book section, also known as the literary porn section for middle aged and elderly women. They had a _NAME_ Grisham book there. I read three of the man's books, and tried to read a few others. The man isn't that great of a writer in my opinion. He can't write a likable character to save his life. I hated every single person in the three I read. I read the Rainmaker, I think it was called, the one where the attorney is trying to get his racist uncle out of the gas chamber, which was the worst of the three (but by far the longest), and The King of Torts, which was doom and gloom for the main cha
racter, until all his problems went away conveniently like they never existed. _PERSON_ not a good writer, I'm sorry, I've never thought he was. Everyone says, ""Oh, A Time to Kill is so great!"" and yeah, it might be, but he has like, twenty-five books after that, AT LEAST. It was his first book, but my god, I tried to read about eight of his books and they were all awful because of the terrible characters and just boring and uninteresting drama. I can get behind modern day writers, I can, but the writers that have their works being sold at grocery stores that are stocked by a vendor are terrible ninety-nine out of a hundred times. The last time I bought a book at that store that wasn't complete shiitake mushrooms was The Hunger Games. I thoroughly enjoyed that book, and I read it in like, two days. Then I went and bought the second and third, and I got about a third of the way through the second and said, ""well, this is disappointing..."" and I stopped. I used to be a Barnes and Noble frequenter many moons 
ago, and the last book I got from there was _NAME_: Vampire Hunter. I was at the store with my homie G, and I saw that and was all ""wow, seriously?"" and he told me that it was actually a really good book, and it is. I'd recommend it highly. The beginning is a little slow, but it gets going early and never stops. It's a wild and exciting ride. With my kindle e-reader, and the fact that I own about twenty trillion leather bound collectible books from the _NAME_ Library or some other big name library, I don't go to Barnes and Noble that much anymore. In fact, I can't tell you the last time I did go there. I think it was with My Home Dawg, and that was, like, I don't know, 2013? Their book selection is top of the line, but everything else is bewilderingly overpriced, but they're known for that though. I used to think, ""I'd like to work here!"" and the same day I gave the manager my application (that's how long ago it was, I used a paper application), I walked around, and heard two people ask really stupid ques
tions to an employee. ""I'm looking for a book that's written like a _PERSON_ book, but I'd like it to be historical fiction,"" was one. I remember giving that guy a weird look when he asked the woman that. To me, that's like, just, I-I don't even know. That's a, ""Oh, let me go ask a manager!"" question, where you say that and then go hide into the backroom and look busy. The other question was, ""Do you have any _NAME_?"" and my immediate response in my head was, ""NO! _PERSON_ and _PERSON_ has NOTHING like that, OBVIOUSLY! Why would you think we did? What are you, stupid?!"" Thankfully, they never called. Also, their tablets/e-readers are garbage. _USER_ID_: If you want an e-reader, either download the Kindle app for your smartphone or get a Kindle E-reader. They're great. 175954719,"I understand and respect the wishes of humanity to be one family in all its diversity, but music contains dissonance as well as harmony, and every scale has an approximation which is a finite cut off, there is such a thing as death, though it is not the end of life. I will give you a concrete example. Two families do not live in the same house or plough the same fields all the time, two people do not occupy the same space. This is what I mean by division and natural order, numbers, perception of what is and what isn’t, distinction, and difference. As another example one woman’s husband is not another’s, one woman’s child is not another’s, families are partially ordered, not linearly and indeed beyond the single partially ordered tree is a whole forest. Divisions is a part of life, it is used for calculating things, working through problems, until they are resolved. So long as we perceive, it cannot be avoided. Should everyone share the same house or are they entitled to separate houses. P
roperty is theft according to _PERSON_, but private property is a right. I am not trying to be political, I am trying to point out the nature of politics. Homosexuality didn’t even cross my mind when I spoke of a natural order, it is a part of life as well, and stating that division is necessary is a simple fact of respecting the private property of others, since to observe is to collapse the wave function."

175954726,"I have been on Lithium since I was 17 or 18 years old, I am now 28. I have been on Invega as well and it’s safe to say your weight gain is coming from Invega, not Lithium. I believe Lithium is relatively weight neutral. The only thing it really does for me is make me more thirsty and want to drink more water, which I do. As far as mood stabilizers go, Lithium is the best out there, for its minimal side effect profile and also its ability to increase grey matter in the brain, reversing the damage episodes cause. Lithium is good for neural plasticity. Lithium prevents both the highs and the lows. If there is such thing as a “wonder drug”, then Lithium is it."

distractions, growth, etc. I don't know what I want because I haven't thought about it yet. I have cognitive impairment now. 175954779,"I have inner dialogues, but not monologues. My thoughts are abstract and condensed, I suspect most people think like this. When problem solving, planning or working out issues related to creative projects, I often slow down my thoughts into proper sentences in order to remember or make something stick. As far as inner dialogues go, it's hard to explain. It's something like acknowledging the different parts of my consciousness and assigning each of them different voices, but not in a literal sense: it's my head, I know who's talking. *The voice in my head that knows the right thing to do but always chooses otherwise. *The voice in my head that knows the correct course of action but is rarely given priority. *The angry, petulant child who I occasionally allow to babble unchecked because it makes me feel better. *The voice of reason who tries to get everyone else to work together or at least slow down, consider things, and act appropriately. They're always bickering. It's when two or more of them come 
to an agreement that I can get things done. I also suspect I have a kind of inner idiot savant who ignores everything but and keeps a kind of running tab on (mostly) external matters, but that's something different."

175954783,"The dark side. I've watched episodes about it as well.. I won't go into detail cuz you know.. But we all love you and don't want this to happen to you or anyone else.. There's so many people that are overdosing more than ever and the same is with eating disorders - Cuz of the pandemic. So many things like this are caused by stress. 90% of my addiction is better. I still dabble in a few soft drugs.. Basically, the baseline for us is like normal life. So don't think of it as going back into the black hole. Why? Because you've been there already. It's not like the first time. And for me, if I got rewarded chemically.. It's much worse for you because it's the opposite - Motivated by feeling bad and culture.. It's all very complicated. If I was educated on English grammar or scientific research, I'd write books, blogs, etc.. It's all trying to understand certain things and 
we learn from each other - Support is key.. I know that you're over it and it's tempting but the temptation doesn't last. Be resilient during those times =]"

175954807,"It was a cbt thing I learned...the therapist told me if things that used to make me happy weren’t working then I should double up the positive energy, I changed it to triple. So you just pick three activities, one each for a different sense. Example ....I like animals so I might visit a zoo and take photos while enjoying a snack or drink, three fun things at once. It amplifies the experience the more you do at once. You might like biking, Some music and one more thing....maybe you’d like to take photos too? Idk but you can pick scented candles or other scent, taste, etc but you need to do at least three things at once. If you can afford it you can also buy something new that’s small, a scented soap, a new type of drink(mocktail)? Maybe cooking a new item is fun for you? Bake some cupcakes while calling a friend and enjoy both the smell and taste and sound. Touch is the most difficult if your alone so break out a squeazy ball or a fidget spinner. Whatever it is three different sense, three act
ivities...."

175954843,"Maybe not that one belief, but I guarantee that you have an emotional connection to some belief. It makes them feel better because it makes them part of a social group. Yes. And that psychological need is ""social belonging"". The truth is what your group (or its leaders or enforcers) say the truth is. Why? Because it makes you part of the group. Well, it's messed up, but it's how the species works as a rule. Note that it is considered a disorder when the kind of truth being argued is ""inconsistent with cultural or subcultural norms"". Again, because it's the goal of social belonging (and only the goal of social belonging) that makes it normal. Ask _PERSON_. https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2KK_kzrJPS8 That's a well-educated modern-day image of someone looking at the moon and crapping their pants. It's fun to think about these things and discuss them and all, but if you're not thinking about it just because it's fun and interesting, then you're getting into belief territory. It's almost comically c
ircular reasoning, and it fundamentally relies on the HUGE assumption that the causation of consciousness can be probabilistically analyzed. It's an entirely arbitrary and unfalsifiable assumption, and there's no scientific indication at all that it's the case (or that it isn't, for that matter). We have no idea what consciousness is, and chances are we'll never know. For all I know, there's no ""we"" to begin with, and I am the only conscious thing that exists. Or maybe the table, the floor and everything else is conscious. One statement is as logically meaningless as the other anyway, when there's no way to even begin to objectively define what consciousness is. _PERSON_ is a smart guy. He knows all this. And, unlike people like Bostrom, he's not a philosopher or a theorist of any kind. He's actually pretty busy with real-world stuff. So why is he fixated on that sort of idea anyway? Do you see my point? Even that, I still think it's down to group cohesion / loyalty / membership. People will sometimes be le
ss afraid of death than they are afraid of ostracism, and they'll act accordingly. I meant that it's not a good idea to carelessly disparage fundamentalists. They make no sense, they're no good, but underestimating their capabilities has the same effect as overestimating their threat: they gain strength. Recent events and current global trends reflect that. I don't know. That's a mystery to me too. There was a period of a few years when I still went to church voluntarily. I thought ""one day I'll understand"". One day I did. So I stopped going. It's expected from kids that they'll outgrow it, and there'll be no negative consequences when they call the adults out on the BS. The same can't be said for religious precepts. Other than that, yes, it's the same. My father went to priest school. He reads the bible every day. If you ask him if the _NAME_ story really happened, he'll say ""Of course not, that's crazy. It's just allegory."" When I tell him about some evidence of mistranslation or misinterpretation or su
spiciously selective editing of Bible passages introduced centuries after original authorship, he loves to hear about it and then go see it for himself. Some people are not as sensible when it comes to those things though. Some communities are not as sensible. So, yes, people will go ""la la la"" for the sake of conformity. Also, think about it. Displaying belief in something obvious and reasonable proves nothing in particular about you. But displaying belief in something arbitrary and unreasonable proves loyalty / submission / conformity. So that's what's demanded . With time, people internalize it (to varying degrees). Questioning the belief becomes mentally indistinguishable from questioning the whole social network that they're often reliant on. It literally overrides logic. That's religion in a nutshell."

Like the past year or so. I wish I felt better."

175954891,"I absolutely can. You might consider trying organic raw cacao nibs. Relatively expensive but you won't need much. Expect to feel like a termite chewing on bitter wood chips and you won't be disappointed, but two or three carefully-timed mounds each the size of a quarter give me superhuman energy and endurance. If I go overboard (as I am wont to do), I can get heart palpitations and have to ""come down"" by eating four slices of quality cheddar cheese, but they don't do a number on me like coke or even speed (which used to be my friend). If these work for you, you will need to brush your teeth before meeting clients, lest your grin reveal hunks of black stuff between your teeth. TMI, but I like to let people know what they're getting into. Good luck."

175954904,"_NAME_ said... You say, ""Every night, even if i elevate my head, i feel a discomfort, a weight in my chest/belly, even if i do stretching, yoga, eat well.."" I have chest discomfort, also, and find that a heating pad helps that. It enlarges the blood vessels and rushes more oxygen and nutrients to the injured area. Do you have a heating pad? I keep mine plugged into the wall by my bed. When I was about 28, I was out of a job, away from people, in my apartment by myself and was getting in such by shape nerve-wise, I knew I should see a psychiatrist. I was the youngest child and never had learned to solve my own problems, always counting on my older siblings and my parents. But now here I was living by myself and having big problems and I didn't know what to do. I knew what to do, but I couldn't do it. My negativity was coming home to roost. It got worse and I finally got to a psychiatrist. Turned out I was bipolar. Turned out my mother's mother was bipolar, so I inherited that, because it can skip 
a generation (my mother didn't have it). In my mother's mother time, 1930's, 40's, they didn't have any medicines for emotional problems, and she spent some years in a state mental hospital 100 miles from home. Today, and for the last 50 years and more, they have many very effective medicines. So I've seen, or heard about, a lot of change. As a bipolar, I'm on Lithium for my mania and Mirtazapine for my depression. And it has been really helpful for the past many years. Have you ever considered going to a psychiatrist? thanks for the message the thing is, i would like to try to heal the physical problem, before eventually considering going to a psychiatrist. Unless, perhaps, it's something in my mind that is provoking this. But i'm super wary of taking any psy medicine, don't want to rely on this."

175954917,"Of course it's better when you're with people - because when you're interacting with them, you don't have as much time to ""talk to yourself"", and you can FEEL the reality of the situation. When you're by yourself, you start telling yourself all sorts of ""lies"", and you believe these pop-up random thoughts to be true. Remember to tell yourself that when you're with people, that is REALITY. When you're by yourself, try reminding yourself that the thoughts that are ""coming to you"" are not REAL, but are actually ""stories"" that you are inadvertently telling yourself. It might take time for you to eventually remember this, but if you tell yourself this EACH time, you will be able to stop yourself sooner before you begin to spiral out. Keep with the CBT - it's supposed to be very helpful for anxiety. Also, I believe it seems to be more apparent in the AMs because you are probably more by yourself then; and, at least for me, there seems to be a connection to AM time and low blood sugar, which can e
xacerbate the jittery feelings. In the evenings, you are probably more tired, so your mind just wants to zone out more rather than start up ""worried"" thoughts. Hope some of this insight helps."

175954970,"My prior response didn't take this into account. I think hallucinations are real experiences, don't get me wrong. They are totally real and valid to the person experiencing them. Oh, and also there's a theory in philosophy called the brain in a vat hypothesis (BIVH for short). Basically it explains a form of skepticism towards reality. The argument generally tries to prove that if we don't know we're not brains in vats, then we should be skeptical about reality. That's a huge aside, but I thought it could be interesting to some people... I don't know if that's related at all to this thread, in all honesty. But I decided to say something about it since it's interesting to me. I guess it is related to hallucinations because we could think of hallucinations as things that lack validity. But if we're brains in vats, then we wouldn't know whether hallucinations were real or not. I think I'm confusing myself here..."

In Belgium hospitals have gotten guidelines to choose who to admit and who to refuse when it might or will be no longer possible to admit everyone in need of care. It's certainly possible that the virus is man-made but I don't care much. I care about getting what I need in case that in 2 weeks from now I get heavily wounded in a car crash and my survival chance or quality of life is deemed too low to help me because others are in a better state than me. 175955037,"I’ve always been an introvert, asocial and sensitive. I was always fine with that. I got married to the love of my life and we live together for almost 10 years now, in a small town in Turkey. Our life is simple and mostly calm, and we like it that way. I’m 35 years old woman who always struggled with anxiety since childhood but I was always proud to say I’m in control and I’m very stable. A vegetarian non-smoker non-drinker. I’ve dealt with the death of both my parents. My dad died from a heart attack when he was 70 and I was 24. My mum got clinically depressed after his death and lived with agoraphobia for 4 years when at some point she got embolism from laying too much and died when it reached her lungs. I was heartbroken but not depressed after all this. I was living abroad with my husband and was kinda relieved that mum will not have to suffer anymore living this way. I thought I was strong... In 2016 I started having too much pain all over my body. My lower abdomen, my jaw, my head, 
my ribs. After going to all kinds of doctors I found through laparoscopic surgery that I have endometriosis. A chronic illness of the reproductive system with no known cure. I was in pain, I was very disturbed and it took me a year to get used to this new reality. At some point I got to a place where I was stable and the pain was not too much. Still I can’t do a lot of physical work without starting to hurt. My husband works for us both. In September 2019 I felt the pain getting worse. It caused me a lot of anxiety and stress. I know I need a surgery to remove the Endometriosis from my internal organs. But I kept postponing it because we need to go to Istanbul for it and my husband was busy at work. Now in January I had something like a mental breakdown. Almost every day for three weeks now I cry without a clear reason. I feel sad for no good reason, almost anything can be a trigger. I know that there is help for my endometriosis and I can’t accept that this is why I cry constantly. My house was always my 
safest place, a place I felt secure and peaceful in. Now I’m afraid of staying alone in it. I feel as if I’m suffocating in it. My mind cannot stop racing, I’m so anxious I can’t stay in one place, I always have to move. I feel very tired both mentally and physically. I’m usually kinda lazy and flegmatique by nature so being so anxious and not being able to sit or lie down without getting a fit of anxiety or a panic attack, is something very unusual for me. I remember my mum and how depressed she was and it scares me so much that I will become like her. I love to be in control of everything I do and think, so this state is terrifying to me. I feel like I can’t control my thoughts. I’m scared of my anxiety and I always have a feeling of dread and a tense spot in my chest. The only thing that helps for now is physical activity like yoga, long walks outside and exercise. I do take hormones for my endometriosis and a very low dose of amitriptyline which is prescribed for chronic pain. This combinati
on served me well for 3 years. But I guess something has to change now. I’ll be having an appointment with my neurologist who also works with people with depression. I really hope that I will gradually get better but I also think I got to a place where it’s easy to say I’m really depressed. And my anxiety is just through the roof. I sometimes experience a fear that I might lose my mind and hurt myself, even though I never did such a thing before. I think this is a compulsive-obsessive thought that gets stuck in my head when I get anxious. Did anyone experience anything like that? A mental and nervous breakdown that they cannot seem to control?"

175955082,"Interesting. When I was psychotic, my hallucinations were of real objects, but had what I call auras or fuzzy wavy boundaries that made the object stand out and impossible to ignore. It went along with the entire theme of my disordered thinking. E.g., Photos of eyes in magazines looked back at me and can see inside me. It was penetrating and terrifying. One time my psychiatrist and I discussed this. She told me this was common. I never had an actual hallucination of an object that wasn't in front of me when I was psychotic. The only time I experienced this was in a state of delirium that was due to anticholingeric syndrome."
175955083,"I would certainly be open to trying medication if things are affecting your quality of life a lot. I took zoloft at a very small dose which has an off label use for dizziness. I was also instructed to take klonopin BEFORE I get on a boat when there are bigger waves. Living in MN and having a desire to fish a lot, I tend to spend time on the water. This is a preventative step that then allows me to do something I love, which in turn helps mentally. So consider the medication, it can help. 175955087,"Yes, therapists can use their position and inside information (what you tell them) to hurt their clients rather than help them. I was in a clinic type situation with about 3 therapists and 3 psychiatrists, and was seeing one of the psychiatrists so figured I could pick one of the therapist from the same office. She was horrible, so I reported her to the office manager. So, they replaced her and I got her replacement, and she was horrible so I again complained to the office manager. Then they got rid of me. So, I would definitely consider reporting her so she won't treat others like that. She's not trying to help you, she's trying to bring you down beneath her. There can be repercussions from the clinic, but I would do it anyway. The first time they might let you get away with it. And the second, if they're OK. I know, it's difficult not to report it. If not in a clinic situation, there might be something on the net search engine called, ""reporting psychiatric/therapeutic malpractice"" and have som
e groups that can help. Think of teenagers going in there for help, and getting hurt instead. It happens a lot in the medical field. 175955111,"Hormone fluctuations (ovulations, Menses) can cause breast pain, tenderness ,swollen, etc. this can happen x-amount of time before your period or ovulation. It might be helpful for you to track ovulation (which happens approximately 2 weeks after your period) and your period (which happens approximately 2 weeks after ovulation). In doing this you might see a correlation between your breast pain and the other symptoms with your cycle. This might decrease your anxiety and could be something to discuss with your GYN. I believe what you are experiencing is more than likely a fluctuations in your hormones. This is something I started to deal with many years ago and it scared me until my GYN explained what I was experiencing. Take care."

175955220,"Childhood Emotional Neglect is both simple in its definition and powerful in its effects. It happens when your parents fail to respond enough to your emotional needs while they’re raising you. Emotional Neglect is an invisible, unmemorable childhood experience. Yet unbeknownst to you, it can hang over you like a cloud, coloring your entire adult life. What makes Childhood Emotional Neglect (CEN) invisible and unmemorable? Several important factors. First, it can happen in otherwise loving, caring families that lack for nothing materially. Second, your parents’ failure to respond is not something that happens to you as a child. Instead, it’s something that fails to happen for you as a child. Our eyes don’t see the things that fail to happen. And so our brains can’t record them. Decades later, an adult, you sense that something is not right, but you don’t know what it is. You may look at your childhood for answers, but you cannot see the invisible. So you are left to assume that something 
is innately wrong with you. “Whatever is wrong, i t’s my own fault,” you secretly believe. “I’m different from other people. Something is missing. I’m flawed.” Yet it’s not your fault . There are answers . And once you understand the problem , you can heal. To keep reading click here: https://blogs.psychcentral.com/childhood-neglect/2017/07/7-signs-you-grew-up-with-childhood-emotional-neglect/?li_source=LI&li_medium=popular17"

175955286,"Is there any reason for a 400GB one instead of a 512GB one? Switch I think is 1080p, so it technically doesn't ""need"" 4K support, but the fast RW speeds are ideal. $30 difference between 400GB and 512GB, but if 512GB is out of your budget, then yeah, 400GB would be fine. But I just thought I'd point out that there isn't a huge price difference. I have a Lexar 128GB high speed micro SD. I just checked and it's this one: https://www.walmart.com/ip/Lexar-128...pter/_PHONE_NO_ Back when I got the switch in 2017, the 128GB cards were like $100, so that's the only reason I have 128 instead of 512 or whatever. 175955289,"I can relate to the stressful, overwhelming job. And I can also relate to the not happy or sad... the blah. Going through the motions. I know it may not be the solution, but alleviating your stress from the job will allow you to think. I thought I would be the last person to say that you have to let go of the job, but I was forced to move into a lower gear, if you will, when my sister lost a child. I could not function normally for a year and a half -- and I'm still not out of it. But it taught me a lot about the time I've spent sweating a &$^(%#%) job!!! I had to cut my consulting work down, and amazingly -- we survived k. The experience made me realize that we would be okay, even if we didn't have as much $. , had never happened). My point is that you have to find different work/something else. 175955290,To anyone reading this that is on benzodiazipines and may not be aware you cannot take benzos for an extended amount of time and quit cold turkey. It can literally kill you. If you just take them occasionally like OP without any effects between doses you should be fine. DO NOT quit benzos cold turkey. Look up the _NAME_ manual for more information. _USER_ID_ does have exemplary use and I commend him for it. The reason benzos are not easily available is due to several factors. Doctors don't want to be responsible if you become dependent and abuse of benzos (particularly Xanax) is quite common. Benzos and opiods are a dangerous mix and sadly many people have fatal effects combining the two for recreational uses. I see some strong feelings about benzos in this thread but I don't think people that use them as needed are weak for utilizing medication as prescribed to them. We are all different. Some only need them once in awhile and some need high doses just to get through the day. At my peak panic attac
k cycle benzos were a miracle drug that enabled me to function. I have slowly tapered down from a high dose to around 2 mg. I will continue to taper until I am benzo free. It is a long process but I feet it will be worth it. A physical need (dependence) for benzos has nothing to do with addiction or an addictive personality. Most people who use a benzo consistently (not once in awhile) for more than 2 to 4 weeks will have to taper off. Your GABA receptors are affected and your body gets dependent. Simple as that. Willpower (unless you are abusing or recreationally using ..please don't do this) has nothing to do with it. If you have been on benzos for any length of time you will need to taper much like _PERSON_ has. This will vary based on individual and medication. I make a cut and wait at least four weeks to cut again for example.

175955319,"I've been considering this for quite a while so below I'll share some personal examples. I'm firm in my belief that we can ""get better"" and overcome most symptoms of our disorder. I don't know (rather doubt) if I'll ever feel like ""normies"" do when they see other people but I can't not work at this slab of granite. I'm really interested to understand how thought processes happen for other schizoids or if I'm alone when I say mine feels like fighting some kind of involuntary defense mechanism. Examples of my day-to-day thinking are difficult to dredge from consciousness even for transmission on this forum. When I reach for something to share things happen automatically and the task is almost impossible. I sort of fight myself in a way? For example those sentences took nearly 10 minutes to type because my mind kept going blank and thinking unrelated thoughts. It's like I'm losing focus or something even though I'm intent to communicate and still ""thinking"". Sometimes I need to like forcefully r
e-engage myself with the real world and even then I feel like I need coaxing to supply real information. My false self seems so strong and if I'm not monitoring it I'll derail myself and be in my fantasy for 20 minutes before realizing it and getting back to the real task. It's infuriating because I have nothing to show for that 20 minutes of what felt like deep thought and oftentimes I can't help it. I'm applying some mindfulness techniques suggested by a therapist with some success. It's incredibly taxing though and by the end of the day I'm mentally exhausted. I hope it's like a muscle so that with time it becomes easier from all the exercise. ^ That's just alone when I'm trying to work ^ With other people in the equation it gets complicated... Automatic withdrawals, deflecting conversations about anything ""real"", intellectualization, complete false-self takeover. My thinking in interactions with others depends who I'm with and why we're together (of course), but just like when alone "" I "" get lost in 
the exchange sometimes. After the event I'm prone to be mad at my inability to be real. This is probably too long already and if you got this far reading it I'm really grateful you took the time. It'd be nice if you could contribute insight into your own thinking when alone or in social settings but even a comment on mine would be good too. I'm open to questions for clarification but please be kind. This wasn't easy to share -?"

175955374,"Hi Caritas and welcome! I am sorry to hear that your fear of heights/stairs is getting to be more challenging for you. I am also sorry to hear that your doctor was not more helpful in finding you the resources and treatment that you need. You must be starting to feel very frustrated and without hope. The good news is there *is* hope to conquer/manage your anxiety! It sounds like what you are dealing with is a specific phobia, and much can be done to help you move past this place where you have gotten stuck as a result of your fears. One thing I recommend is specifically asking your doctor for a therapy referral. This will help you in two ways. *One*, you will learn the skills you need to overcome your fear of going down the stairs. There are specific steps to exposure therapy that will challenge you, but eventually help free you to do the things you want and need to do! The *second* thing a therapist can help ascertain is whether or not an Rx is the right choice for you as part of your treatment pl
an. Antidepressants *are* prescribed for anxiety. This is not to say that you are dealing with depression...but the medication does help with both issues. This is why your doctor prescribed it...but if you are reluctant to take it...asking your therapist for either a second recommendation on this...or his/her opinion that therapy alone will suffice for you, will give you a clear direction! Another thing that you can get started on right away is self help. At the top of our main forum page here you will find our Resource Guide. In it you will find Therapy Worksheets as well as links specifically for dealing with phobias. Take a look and give the exercises a try. You will likely find them very helpful! Keep posting with us as well. We understand, care and support is key! Talk soon, _PERSON_ Cat"

175955388,"So to reiterate something I say here periodically, there are two parts to a diagnosis. One is all those criteria, the other is that it has to cause some kind of disadvantage or harm to the person. Depending on the point in my life, I've switched back and forth between having a disadvantage or harm and not. When you've got a stable lifestyle, autonomy, independence, all those schizoid traits can be potentially fine. They might just think you're eccentric. At the moment I'm making decent money and being tolerated, though I don't know how long that will last. Life is good. To me the biggest difference with a narcissist is that they still hinge on some kind of peer response. Maybe they pick something like intellect, sex appeal, etc. But if they ever obtain true inherent confidence, they'll lose the rest of the narcissist baggage in time. The schizoid may or may not have escaped that baggage, but their core difference as far as I understand it is the ""schizo"" bit, or rather more normally the word ""sp
lit."" The schizoid could be a narcisist as well, but the beginning of that diagnosis is that mind-body split. For good and ill, the schizoid person has a ""split"" between the mind/mental and body/physical to one degree or another in one way or another. Where the N seems to be desperate for validation of something, the Schizoid could just as well have that or not, but there's definitely some kind of impulse or overlap where being one or the other can push you towards the other. Hense why I feel like I can ""rip and shred"" narcissists a bit. Because I'm so similar, but different enough, I tend to be able to see their flaws and am largely immune to their tools."

175955504,"When we speak about narcissism, we often focus on the individual. He or she is narcissistic. He or she is a victim of a narcissist. Yet what about those victims who are bullied and targeted by groups filled with narcissistic individuals or in a group where the narcissistic pack leader has toxic enablers? What happens when there is a conspiracy led by an entire group against one individual? Contrary to popular belief, narcissism can and does run in group dynamics too – it just plays out on an even more massive and destructive scale. Rather than one partner abusing another, there is an entire group working to undermine and plot against a chosen target. This is especially harmful to any chosen victim because research shows that social rejection activates the same areas of the brain as physical pain (_PERSON_, et. al 2011). Theoretically, being emotionally abused by a manipulative group can be at times just as painful as being physically assaulted. The frontrunners of such a group use enablers or wha
t is colloquially termed “flying monkeys” to ensure that the recipients of such bullying are properly silenced (_PERSON_, 2017). This is also known as “mobbing,” where a toxic individual enlists the help of others to carry out his or her vicious campaign and dirty work against another individual (_PERSON_, 2013). We see this unhealthy, abusive dynamic play out within the realm of the narcissistic family unit, friendship circles, workplaces and anywhere there is a possibility for bullying. This form of conspiracy may not be technically “illegal,” but it poses great harm to those who are targeted. The target suffers through unbelievable emotional, verbal, perhaps even physical abuse at the hands of the toxic group, who uses them as a scapegoat for the group’s problems and deviant desires. Therapist _NAME_ (2017) writes that: “The purpose of a scapegoat is to pass responsibility onto someone else. Usually this person is unsuspecting at first and agrees because they are trying to get along with ot
hers. This technique of passing the buck is very common with narcissists, sociopaths, and addicts. Narcissists can’t allow their ego to be tarnished by an error. Sociopaths do it for the sport of it.” For an excellent example of how a narcissistic group dynamic can undermine and scapegoat one individual, one needs to look no farther than the devastating bullying Today Show co-host _NAME_ suffered under the reign of _NAME_ (who has now been exposed as a sexual predator) and her colleagues back in 2011. According to Vulture, executive producer _NAME_ Bell reportedly launched what was known as “Operation Bambi,” a mission to eradicate _PERSON_ from the team, early on in her employment (he denies this, of course). She was subjected to not only _PERSON_’s mistreatment but also exclusion, taunting and bullying by her other colleagues as a result. In 2012, a clearly traumatized _PERSON_ was forced to leave the show in a highly televised exit despite the fact that she was, and remains today, a highly talent
ed, empathic and one-of-a-kind journalist. In fact, NBC lost more than a fifth of its audience after her departure. This example illustrates something deeply important: groups with one or more sociopaths do not target people who are incompetent. On the contrary, they target those who threaten the status quo in some way. _PERSON_ represented the type of conscientious, empathic and sincere person that juxtaposed _PERSON_’s own predatory personality and threatened the group dynamic of keeping toxic behavior under the wraps. Since the corporate world tends to favor and promote sociopathic individuals, they chose _PERSON_’s preferences over _PERSON_’s potential and incredible abilities to connect with her viewers in a deeply compassionate way. To make the conspiracy all the more effective, the victim is further silenced by what makes them so special in the first place – their ability to be discerning, their sensitive nature, their compassion, is used to paint them as unhinged should they dare speak out. Th
e victim’s own wounds are played with. The narcissistic group feeds upon the victim’s insecurities and vulnerabilities to ensure that the victim feels too powerless to complain or take action. They identify the wounds and weaknesses of the target. They also use the target’s strengths against him or her. They emotionally blackmail their targets. They exhaust their targets. They gaslight their targets into believing that the abuse isn’t occurring. And ultimately, they bully them into contributing to the group’s deviant agenda. The manipulative leaders of narcissistic conspiracies find ways to covertly abuse the victim so they can escape accountability for their actions. The victim is made to feel like and look like the “crazy” one – and everyone is able to avoid individual responsibility for inflicting harm and participating in the conspiracy. In all narcissistic “conspiracies,” this scapegoat is a “black sheep” who is treated like an outsider of the group. This chosen black sheep is the
n terrorized, taunted, excluded, persecuted and becomes the site of many projections or unfair blame for the mistakes of the narcissistic group. The group has no problem using the victim to advance their agenda or add to their resources, but they fail to recognize or reward the efforts of that individual in a fair way. In fact, the harder the scapegoat works to win the approval of the group, the more the scapegoat is persecuted. Since the group is usually led by one or more narcissistic or sociopathic individuals, very little mercy or empathy is given to the victim. The victim suffers emotional terrorism at the hands of ruthless individuals who prey on his or her vulnerabilities and weaknesses. Narcissists and sociopaths usually choose those they are envious of and threatened by. These victims are exploited for their strengths, but demeaned, teased and made to feel like outsiders, just as _PERSON_ was. The alienation takes a toll on victims of group bullying, as they may isolate themselves even more just to a
void further persecution. How And Why Is The Victim Chosen? The target that is chosen to be bullied and ostracized from the group is one that is threatening in some way. It could be because they threaten the narcissistic leaders or enablers in their intelligence, appearance, resources, determination, ambition, social aptitude, wealth, independence – or whatever other quality that evokes their envy or fear. In the dynamics of a family with one or more narcissistic individuals as caregivers, the scapegoat is the child or children who are most devalued and demeaned, made to feel less than. These children are often outspoken, sensitive, empathic and have integrity. They present a threat to the existing dysfunction of the toxic family unit, so they are inevitably punished. They are pitted against the “golden children” (children who are excessively overvalued and spoiled in exchange for their blind obedience) and triangulated so that there is a sense of competition, distrust and supreme allegiance to the narc
issistic parent or parents in the household. In a group that is not familial, such as friendship circles or the workplace, the chosen victim is usually someone new to the group or a long-standing member who “dares” to question the authority of the narcissists or sociopaths within that group and is thus excommunicated. These victims may at first be idealized and love-bombed. They are subjected to praise, laser-focused attention, gifts and false promises to lure them into the group. They are “groomed” to feel like a part of the group, which often has many cult-like qualities which discourage dissent and discussion. There are implicit rules to never unmask the toxicity of the group or its decisions. Questions are always met with ambiguous or vague answers or outright reprimands and punishment. The victim’s duty is to keep quiet, remain a scapegoat and not make a fuss about carrying out dirty work for the group. So long as the victim abides by these silent rules, they win temporary safety through their 
obedience. The authority of the narcissistic members of the group is upholded as the final say, regardless of fairness or equity. As soon as the victim starts to question the dynamics of the group, however, or the group feels like the new victim might potentially “overthrow” the hierarchy in some way, the victim is then “put back” in his or her place. They may be publicly humiliated in front of other members of the group, they may be dismissed, they may be shut down and stonewalled. They may have an ongoing smear campaign against them by the leaders or enablers of those leaders regarding their character, stability and ability to be within the group. It is easy to make the victims of group bullying seem like the unhinged ones – the most abusive people, the leaders of the group, work hard to drive their targets over the edge and push all of their emotional buttons. Groupthink and The Bystander Effect Not all group members of the cult-like conspiracy are unempathic, but when they participate in enablin
g behavior, it creates a collective consciousness, what psychologists call “groupthink” in which a narcissistic unit works together to render the victim powerless enough so that the victim either feels unable to exit or even becomes “trauma-bonded” in some way to the group as a way to survive (Rosenblum, 1982). Those who see the victims being bullied and yet fail to do anything about it usually encounter what it known as “The Bystander Effect,” in which individuals feel as if they don’t have to intervene, especially as the group gets larger, because personal accountability is diminished (_PERSON_, 2014). The chosen target usually has empathy, resilience and is authentic in their integrity. They are agreeable, kind and conscientious to a fault, which makes them ideal prey for sociopathic predators. They are open and willing to consider other perspectives, so they are taken advantage of easily by narcissistic leaders and their enablers. This is very threatening to a group that works best without i
ntegrity or fairness. These are all qualities narcissists look for to ensnare their victims, but of course, most narcissistic groups realize that such qualities also make these victims powerful as well. Truth-tellers are commonly scapegoated in groups where there is toxicity brimming beneath the surface. The target fulfills the following roles: As a convenient scapegoat. They take the blame for any errors or mistakes the narcissistic group or leaders don’t want to be held accountable for. They become the outlet for any projections, rage, dissatisfaction that the group wants to dump on them. A target for an ongoing smear campaign in which the narcissistic individuals involved spread rumors, gossip and misinformation to make you look like a “troublemaker.” This ensures that other group members also fear calling out the toxic dynamics of the group because they don’t wish to be associated with you or your “antics.” To obscure the truth and further the group’s selfish agenda, whatever that might be. 
They stroke the narcissist’s ego – they are made to feel diminished so that the narcissists in the group feel superior. It feels especially gratifying for them to take down a person who is more successful and well-liked (at least initially before scapegoating begins) than they are. They are used to strengthen closer alliances among the already existing cliques in the group. Membership in the group is emphasized and seen as exclusive and coveted because there are “outsiders” who can’t get in. If you are a victim of scapegoating or a black sheep, take heart. You were chosen because you have the qualities that narcissists lack. You were chosen because you were threatening. You were chosen because you were powerful. They saw that power in you, and they wanted to take it away. Though it appears now that wolves in sheep’s clothing rule the world, it is actually scapegoats who have the power and ability to lead others – authentically. When the black sheep finds community, validation and resources to he
lp them thrive after the experiences of being persecuted and alienated, they reconnect with the amazing qualities that made them a target in the first place. Rest assured that karma does come for those who conspired against them – and predators like _PERSON_ are always eventually exposed in due time. Scapegoats can and will rise above the conspiracy – and they can grow stronger in spite of it. References"
