174342047,"Hello everyone, I have been feeling psychotic 'on and off' for many years now. I think it was more consciously hidden by myself before now, due to not wanting others to know how ill, alone and scared I felt. I had an awful traumatic childhood including a narrcissistic mother and secret abuse from my father for 12 years. Schizophrenia is in my father's side of the family. His sister got diagnosed later in adulthood and she went from being so clever, having a Scholarship to not being able to cope with the basics of day to day living, let alone work. I remember her in her dressing gown all the time, drinking coffee, which is coincidentally what comforts me. I hate the world right now, I suppose I always have done. I have encountered many nasty people and situations along the way. Even this 'SARS-Co-vid-19' virus is not making others grateful for what they have. They have to start fights with others in public. The world will get back to normal at some point, whatever normal is!? I last recall feeling t
his bad when I lived alone in my flat, I tried to keep down 3 jobs at one time to pay for it, and I just ended up getting so overwhelmed and stressed (what I classified as feeling 'mad'). This occurred when I moved out of my parents home (against their wishes), because my father wouldn't stop molesting me. I couldn't function properly and had suffered so much emotional abuse (from both parents), that I was scared to be in the 'big' world. I still am terrified. This brings me on to just a couple of hours ago. The NHS called the police round because I had to ring up to say I wasn't coping anymore at the moment. I was desperate, and couldn't avoid asking for help much longer. This manic depressive episode has lasted 6 months, I've lost 10 kilo in weight and I don't want to eat. Lots of triggers have contributed to this current downfall. Arguing with my hubby about not cheating on him (he suspects I have been, as I am psychotic and I have lost so much weight). He admits he is paranoid at times, I have to stress t
hrough no fault of his own. I can't deal with confrontations and arguing. Ironically, I usually have to shout at the top of my voice to defend myself as a human being (with a kind conscience and soul). Otherwise, I lie in my bedroom and ignore the disturbing issue. I have been instructed by Psychiatry that I have Borderline Personality Disorder. I am now fighting for a second opinion as I was told at therapy I did not need further counselling. I strongly disagree, I'd waited for a year to get an appointment, which anyone with pending mental health issues will understand is a struggle! This was another trigger, having my beliefs diminished that I needed further help. I have been told group therapy is my only option, I can't face that as life is overwhelming enough. I don't feel able to cope socially and have lost my faith that there are still kind people out there. The police officers were great, more helpful than psychiatry. They managed to get someone from mental health to speak to me within their visit and 
thankfully, the doctor will ring me this morning to ask more questions about my symptoms/Schizophrenia traits. The police lady could see I was very distressed, muddled and not coping mentally. She was so helpful in getting me some assistance. The doctor will ask a few more questions in the morning and discussed possibility of trying an antipsychotic, such as _PERSON_. I mentioned to him I'd been taking 3mg Buccastem (used from migraines, nausea and Schizophrenia). This is obviously a very small dose, but I double up if needs be and this has greatly helped with calming down the psychotic episodes, helping me to think straighter and not having conflicting voices telling me to kill myself and also thoughts of vengeance have decreased somewhat. The lady at NHS mental health then rang to follow up. She agreed Stemetil sounded effective, and 'good'. As usual, I have slipped through the net. However embarrassing this whole event may sound, I am glad I've stood my ground. The guy on the phone for NHS 111, was less th
an helpful (telling me what I didn't already know, and that there was no option but group therapy!). I proper had a go at him anyway - while frequently apologising! I'm sorry, but some people can't cope in a group, especially me!! I am pleased I am getting some promising help. I hope I feel better and moreso, 'like myself' soon. It is a shame how far you have to go to get a second opinion. It's mad to think that I got in my car the previous night, on all my medication and went on a frenzied drive to try and kill myself, no seatbelt. It's so amazing, the police helped me feel I can survive another day, even if just to wait for the psychiatry doctor to ring. I thanked them so much. It's a shame my other mental health doctors have let me down. Best Wishes to all and thanks for listening. x"

175955511,"A lot of people are curious as to what it feels like to live with bipolar disorder. Now, I am only speaking for myself because everyone’s case – his or her life – is different. Some people liken it to riding a roller coaster and, in a way, it is. It is fast. I have what is referred to as rapid cycling bipolar which means like a pin ball machine my moods clash around in all directions crossing paths with itself. Basically I go from full throttle to behind everyone else quite quickly – month to month, week to week, day to day, or hour to hour. I keep everyone on their toes. Back to the roller coaster, where are each of us going? Well, we are running a course of mood shifts (bipolar disorder is a mood disorder) from very high to very low. Sometimes it is fun, sometimes to the outsider it looks fun, but it is those fun times that wind people living with bipolar disorder in trouble. Those ‘fun’ times are in reference to mania or hypomania. During these phases or ‘episodes’ (what they cal
l them in the psychiatric world) a number of activities can occur. One person may be highly promiscuity, another may spend tons of money without a care in the world – we are all different. I, for example, like to climb up high – trees, three story houses – believing I can fly. But like a bad hangover, when come out of these episodes, we shake our head and deal with the what we have done while hypomanic or manic. Sometimes there is a lot of damage done. Relationships can be broken. Our bank accounts can be drained. I wonder what would have happed if I kept walking on that roof? Don’t get me wrong, it can feel amazing – that is actually a symptom. We experience a feeling of grandeur, like we are the center of everything interesting. We are interesting and talented and amazing and we want everyone to know. Sometimes we may even feel we are God. Oh, to feel that high all the time, amazing. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/being-bipolar/2019/03/31/what-does-it-feel-like/"
175955512,I might work today. I feel like my avolition was med-related maybe. We'll see.
175955513,I have been through what u r feeling. Things will be better. Try talking to a counselor. Do things you love and enjoy. Self care really helps. Share what u r feeling with your loved ones. Don't bottle up your feelings. Hope you feel better soon :)

175955615,"You've been on the medicine 3 days. So it is having a chance to work. Glad you feel better. Sorry you had been living unstable for years. What was that like? What had they done, miss-diagnosed you as anxiety, then finally bipolar? You asked, ""What were your symptoms"" Symptoms of bipolar were, one was depressed. I would go into the psy. office as depressed, the psy, wouldn't say anything, he would just listen to me talk. See my as depressed, dx me as depressed. Wrong. Could have said, do you ever have any manic episodes? I was miss-diagnosed for about 15 years. Signs of my bipolar were: In manic phase, couldn't slow my mind down. Hard to concentrate at times but could occasionally stay on a task for a long time, probably obsessing. Would go until I had a collapse of some sort. One time I couldn't walk for a few hours, probably because of no socialization and obsessing on a project and not on any medicine such as anti-depressant or stabilizer such as Lithium. My mind just refused to keep going 100 
miles an hour. Laid in the ER for a few hours, socialization, then got up and walked out. Was put on anti-depressant alone, and with no stabilizer, the anti-depressant by itself would throw me into mania. Then I would have panic attacks. And the psy. wouldn't have a clue when I went back to see him again. You said, ""The Trazodone has me agitated, so every antidepressant has done this, ridiculous"" Yes, that is ridiculous. For the Trazadone anti-depressant, webmd.com says under side effects: ""This medication may increase serotonin and rarely cause a very serious condition called serotonin syndrome/toxicity. The risk increases if you are also taking other drugs that increase serotonin....(see Drug Interactions section). ""Get medical help right away if you develop some of the following symptoms: .... unusual agitation/restlessness."" Depakote (stabilizer): ""A small number of people who take anticonvulsants for any condition (such as seizure, bipolar disorder, pain) may experience depression, suicidal thought
s/attempts, or other mental/mood problems. Tell your doctor right away if you or your family/caregiver notice any unusual/sudden changes in your mood, thoughts, or behavior...."" What, a lot of anti-depressants raise the serotonin level, which seems to be the chemical which makes us feel good? What other anti-depressants have you taken?"

These signs can range from changes in their mood and behavior, to the loss of a job or destroyed relationships. These signs all point to one thing - Adderall abuse. Addiction is a threat to a person’s health and happiness and drug treatment is needed as soon as possible.” adf.org. said: “Amphetamines are stimulant drugs, which means they speed up the messages travelling between the brain and the body. Some types of amphetamines are legally prescribed by doctors to treat 
conditions such as attention deficit hyperactivity disorder (ADHD) and narcolepsy (where a person has an uncontrollable urge to sleep). Amphetamines have also been used to treat Parkinson’s disease. Other types of amphetamines such as speed are produced and sold illegally. The more potent form is crystal methamphetamine (ice)."

I noticeably lose focus in my day to day because of this, and I’m not sure if this is just major anxiety, but I constantly feel slightly dizzy and light headed as well. On top of that I just feel very uncomfortable in my head, because of this feeling, and it’s like a cycle of pressure that builds up because I focus too much on this weird feeling To give an example, if you watch a horror film, sometimes the camera will focus on one character close up... and then zoom out slowly. The character in the frame will not move, staying the same size, but everything around it slowly pulls back. 
Instead of things pulling back they slightly move left and right, as if I was on a large ship and it was rocking with the water. It’s at its worst point when I wake up on my side, or if I’m very tired at night... I thought it might’ve been vertigo, but I’ve seen many doctors, which all have said your deficient in vitamin D take 2000 units, or it’s just anxiety here’s Xanax... finally one recommended a neurologist, and he thinks it could be an electrical flare affecting the vision portion of my brain. I took the MRI on my brain, and still have to go for the follow up with the doctor to see the results... but it’s not like I have an aneurysm or tumor, because I don’t think they’d just let me walk out Iike that without informing me. Tomorrow morning I have an EEG which measures the electricity in the brain to see if there’s anything wrong with there. This feeling started when I was 11 years old, and went away after two weeks... I’ve disclosed my drug use to every doctor I’ve had and each 
have said I shouldn’t be feeling this way from any of them, and if so not for this long... the fact that I’ve felt this before reassures me a bit that it’s not from previous drug use. I’ve smoked a lot of pot from the ages of 17-22, I’ve done mushrooms 4 times, MDMA 8 times, acid twice with the second time being fake acid I believe since it had a metallic taste (25-I) But this condition started happening over a year after my last ‘mind altering’ substance Since this started again I have been working out everyday, eating a very well balanced diet, taking vitamins daily, trying to think positively, and consuming positive material... I quit playing video games, cut tv use to just an hour or two at most a day of any tv at all... and started trying to paint, learn instruments... basically forcing myself to do so much I don’t have a chance to think in the moment about how I feel, and by the time I do I’m exhausted and pass out to bed The weird thing is the only time I feel completely normal, is in 
my dreams. So if you guys are still experiencing this issue, there are more out there feeling similar, or worse... which can be relieving I guess... try to constantly be positive, it’s an active process and maybe meditation to give your mind time to soothe itself from negative thoughts surrounding this issue. Everyday is a blessing, and just having the cognitive ability to even write this is something I’m grateful for."

174342336,"After all the years of struggling with severe anhedonia, many things have happened since then. I believe it was caused by environment factors (But your dad has schizophrenia.. On the other hand, don't give up. I didn't give up. I kept researching constantly trying to find everything under the sun that would make me better - 50 different chemicals, spirituality, life experiences, support from friends and family - It's all needed) so it can be fixed by environmental factors. I didn't realize that it was environmental factors and of course it was genetics too and/because why didn't it happen to anyone else with the same environmental factors? What I know is that most people in Ireland seemed to be a ""feeling"" type of personality. I was molded into ""thinking"". Probably that has nothing to do with anything but I'm good at piecing all of these things together as time goes on.. The more you know and with creativity, I can explain it better. Think about your whole life constantly and try to remember th
ings that happened. Use the ""windows"" of anhedonia to think about the past and feel those emotions - All the imagery of pictures in your mind (Which I find to be a form of controlled hallucinating). It was my thing to try and figure it out (Even though I still get anhedonia when I withdraw from phenibut). But what I've noticed is that - By feeling that way (By having a lack of feeling), it's ok. I always hope that it will get better. You see why people with bipolar don't realize that they're depressed when they're in depression and some of them end up committing suicide. The brain in the current state says ""I'm gonna be like this forever"". That's how bad trips happen. Psychedelic trips last for 6-12 hours and I've felt the most euphoric possible and the most dysphoric as completely possible. Nothing could feel as good and as bad as those trips. I don't recommend it. I really don't (Only when there's research and clinics where you can walk in, have a guided trip and then walk out looking at the flowers at 
the front door..). I'm not really afraid of pain anymore. I'm ready for complete hell because at least it's ""feeling something"". Not many people would say that if they haven't been through anhedonia. It could have been from my depression and not schizophrenia which was likely. Sometimes depression means not feeling anything at all.. Instead of those melancholy type sadness that people get to be able to write good songs, poems, art, make good music. Anhedonia is really one of the worst things. I would hate to feel anxiety or dissociation but that basically means that I'm not ""all there"". What I mean is to be fully there.. Not feeling anything. I was always afraid of what people think of me when I'm in a bad state but the best thing to do is talk about it with people that don't judge and have acceptance. Being in anxiety states, pain or not feeling anything - You have to have some sort of hope - Otherwise, what's the point? You let what it could be become non-existent in exchange for giving up. You're doing 
a lot of things. Working, writing your books, studying philosophy (Interesting thinkings), having time to relax with a beer or so, finding a partner, etc etc... It's all crazy stuff when you really think about it.. You have a dying passion for life from that crystalized mindset of what it used to be nonetheless and that will get you through it. 175955776,"Dear searching, we sound allot alike. I have been miserably ill for the past three or four months. Hair loss, vertigo, nausea, vomiting, constipation, tender sore throat, hoarse voice, sore ears and cold. I have been running to the nurse practitioner who does very little. She has branded me “Chronic” like a scarlet letter. Finally in a moment of clarity a week ago I thought, “maybe I should check my meds?”....I was so sick and desperate to figure it out too. Guess what? My meds were mixed up! Back in Nov I had asked her to fill my nortriptyline as I was having pain that was keeping me awake.....she filled it wrong, with amitriptyline. I don’t take amitriptyline. Put them on a shelf and forgot about them, ....they look the same as my synthroid....so in Feb when I went to get my synthroid for my pill box I mixed them up! I was taking no thyroid meds but was taking amitriptyline. What a bloody mess. Never in thirty years has this happened to me. Taking the wrong meds...justdoesn’t happen. 
Thus all the symptoms. Fixed the issue but began with terrible muscle cramping. Ended up at the ER the other night where they found my CK enzyemes to be really high. Creatinine kinease or something, a by product of muscle wasting and kidney issues.... Was referred to an endocrinologist and was told it would be several weeks, eight....before they could retest my TSH levels and before I’d feel better.....crazy story....moerto come I’m sure but it goes to show you that even in our darkest hours we know more about our body than they do. Keep fighting, use the ER if it gets too bad though. Feel better soon. _PERSON_"

175955820,"Schizotypals have ""magical thinking"" and odd beliefs and frames of reference. They believe in weird things...like maybe they believe movies or music have special messages just for them, or maybe they believe ghosts can talk to them by moving their laundry around. Schizoids do have daydreams, and sometimes create elaborate stories or fantasy lives....but we don't believe them. We know they aren't real."

175955823,"Sometimes just waiting for them to call you won't help you get it faster. Here in our state someone has a facebook group on just locating shots. It has helped so many find one. One thing you can do is call local pharmacy's and ask to be on a waitlist. They can give you shots that someone didn't show up for or leftovers etc. Look at all the places that are offering the shot, walmart, cvs etc. and see if they have a sign up list. They do often and aren't the type of place that calls you to offer a shot, you have to sign up for it yourself."

The main thing to remember with health anxiety is to not use Dr _PERSON_ as that will only help fuel your anxiety. 175955832,"Surely truth, or at least the search for truth, is the only way to rational, non-deluded contentment. You could argue that schizoid people value comfort over truth. I'm quite content with what I have, and I can't just ""decide"" to believe something just because it makes me feel better. How do people do that? How do they turn off the voice that screams ""this is obviously bollocks"" when you decide that believing in the tooth fairy would make you happier? To an extent, I admire people who can. Going through life with the idea that nothing really matters because Jesus will sort it out when you die must be great, but how they do that to the point where they'll accept it and defend it as ""real""? It's beyond me. In the sadism thread there's a discussion about serial killers. Their mentality provides them comfort over truth. I'd imagine that most people would agree that truth is more important."

175955835,"At low dose, 1-4 grams it's a stimulant. At 5-8 grams, it's an opioid. There's different strains (White strain is more stimulating, red strain is more relaxing and green strain is in between). I have all 3 different strains and only tried the red strain so far. But I don't feel the effects of opiates/opioids. Just relaxation, calmness, meditativeness. I took 5g before my job resume appointment in half an hour."

175955841,"My understanding is that Bi polar comes in cycles. For example you can have periods of mania then periods of depression with some normal times in between. These cycles can last for days, weeks or evens months at a time. It's been a long time since I've had an actual mood cycle that last for days or weeks at a time. on average my mood tends to fluctuate daily. Some depression some irritability sometimes mild impulsiveness and some mild anxiety. I guess this is my baseline mood. I don't seem to have classic bi polar symptoms but am diagnosed with Bi polar 2. My questions is, does anyone else here experiencing daily mood shifts like I do. If so is this typical for bi polar particularly bi polar 2. Could this just be my baseline mood? I've been like this before starting meds and during. I've discussed this with my psychiatrist and he say's it's rare that someone would have daily mood shifts compared to classic bi polar cycles. The questions is are we dealing with bi polar or something else. For example 
life stressors that are contributing to my mood. Possibly ADHD. he didn't seem quite sure but seems more concerned with keeping my depression and hypomania level. Just trying to make sense of this condition outside of the textbook symptoms. Thank you very much."

175955855,"Being kind to yourself and ensuring that you are setting yourself up for success each day becomes even more important when you are living with extra challenges such as bipolar disorder or other mental illnesses. Life is hard enough to navigate when you are fighting your mind, so it’s important that you are proactive in doing all that you can to support yourself. From my own experience, these are some of the things that I have learnt can really help to get prepared for the day ahead, even when you are going through a tough time: Eating well While having a good diet is not going to solve all of your problems by any means, ensuring that you are getting the right nutrition for your mind and body to function at their best, is a great way that you can really help to set yourself up for success. This isn’t always easy especially if you’re not in a stable state of mind, but trying your best to do this, even if only in small ways like making sure you eat one piece of fruit each day is a small victory. 
Asking for help to ensure that you are eating well is something that can be really beneficial if you don’t feel up to planning, shopping or cooking yourself. Something that myself and my husband do is food prep when I am feeling good, which I find really helpful because it means that I have healthy meals there ready to just heat up. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/bipolar-journey/2019/10/setting-yourself-up-for-success-despite-bipolar-disorder/"
175955856,"It is a serotonin modulator, many side effects at start up. Not recommended in under 24 years of age. It is an anti depressant, and comes also as an extended release, or is just one, must delve further. Extended release will take time, as it is like a foundation treatment, in the background thus start up can be an issue. Regular chats with dr is recommend at this point. HT"

175955932,"I'm a ""tea""-totaler, and drink tea all day long. I drink good tea that I buy through online shops. You can read their story at their web site: https://www.renegadetea.com Tea has less caffeine and does not make me jumpy and jittery the way coffee does. It also has the amino acid L-theanine, which causes ""relaxed alertness"" by increasing the brain's alpha waves."
175955933,"April of this past year marked the seventh anniversary of my dad's passing. He died April 1st 2013. April Fools Day, in Hospice, from cancer. He had only just turned 54 less than a month prior. He was a father of two adult children. Divorced and remarried. He had 3 grandchildren through that union. He was starting the process of becoming a foster parent for crisis situations. A safe house. He played the acoustic guitar. Was a water color artist. He loved history. He was quiet and reserved yet he and could spend 5 hours on the phone together. He and my mom had my when they were 19. There was never a moment in my 34 years with him that I did not feel loved and encouraged and like the most important person in his world to him. A machinist. Homemade handyman. He planted over 200 blueberry bushes for a blueberry farm. We raised chickens. He loved to fish. He did not like to hunt. We always had cats and thanks to my dad, we got a dog. He loved being outside and enjoying God's earth. He loved to hike and 
explore. My dad was my hero and my everything. Over seven years later...it is not any easier. I miss him every moment of every day."

175955937,"To focus, I need a change of scenery - Rooms where I have a desk, places to go and just think or listen to podcasts, being able to go outside and feel warm, supportive friends that like to work on themselves and don't go to parties and get blackout drunk or stoned every other night or make drama, a part time job that I like where I can save money.. I need lots of recreation so I can think about things that help my soul so I can feel comfortable about those things while focusing. I want to feel safe and secure in my environment. I need to have the perfect meds and be satisfied and not have to think about them anymore. My dad is coming to visit at the end of the month. I'm so lucky that he survived cancer. He's like a shaman to me. I think he's an INFJ or something.. He tells me things about myself and is good at guiding me. He was there for me when I was in the basement, suffering abuse and madness. We'd talk on the phone for hours while I'd pase, walking around looking at the kitchen tiles and maki
ng patterns with my feet. There's so many people that I meet that are like that. They understand. I just need to know that things will be ok. I feel alone with my thoughts and lost. 175956002,"Hi Mountainside, You have gone through a lot, but I know you are not a coward. There is a strong, vibrant woman inside of you and with her help you can get through this! Now, I am not any sort of healthcare professional, I'm just an old lady that has seen a lot so I have some advice for you but first a little about me. I am 74 and suffer a severe autoimmune disease, systemic scleroderma to be exact and so I know all about physical pain, loneliness and depression. My Scleroderma doesn't have many outward signs, the damage is mostly internal and friends would look at me and say that I wasn't sick. My hubby was partially physically disabled and had Alzheimer's disease. I was his caregiver for 10 years, taking care of his physical needs while I watched him decline mentally to the point that the man I married just wasn't there anymore. He passed away a couple of months ago after 52 years of marriage. I have had many times when I was in so much physical pain that I just didn't want to move, but I had no 
choice, he needed constant care and attention. The mental and emotional stress nearly broke me many times as I watched my friends disappear, they just couldn't understand my illness or the stress I was under. Anyway, here is what I learned. You are your own advocate. Your emotional health is primarily up to you. That is not to say that you don't need a counselor, after all, I have 2. Look up the Mental Health Hot Line in your area, they should be able to point you to a therapist to help you. When you are down, I want you to look out the window and find something interesting and beautiful to appreciate. Concentrate on beauty. Look at your children and see the good in them. Look at your husband. The bright, vibrant lady inside you chose him over all others, so I know there are good points about him - find them and concentrate on the good! If you are a spiritual person, read the Bible or the religious works that you find comforting. Whenever your mind gets a negative thought, immediately banish it and concentrat
e on something positive and uplifting. I have a large framed photograph of a hibiscus bloom that I look at if there are no flowers in bloom and coffee table books of fine art to look at. See how many birds you can see from your window or better yet, go outside and look for them. Do not dwell on sorrow! Watch funny TV shows so you can get great big belly laughs, The Big Bang Show, I Love _NAME_ and the _NAME_ Show are my go to shows for laughter. Do what ever it takes to get those laughs. Get some exercise, even if it is only walking for 5 minutes at a time in the house, it will help. If you can get outside, go for a walk, the fresh air and exercise will be wonderful. Laughter and exercise both release those feel good hormones in our brains that will lift our mood and reduce our pain, both mental and physical. So exercise and laugh - a lot! And most of all I want you to remember that you are a valuable person and God Loves You! I'm praying for you! _NAME_-51"

However, once I eat (home-cooked chicken, a tiny amount of rice, organic broccoli, and _PERSON_ pre-grated sharp cheddar), I will almost certainly feel solid and at peace. One of the things I've been doing, in order to combat my various pathologies, is trying to observe my mood fluctuations, finding their immediate cause, and instead of st
aying angry at this or that other person, taking responsibility for my bad feeling . When I remember to do this, I feel a lot better. My sleep schedule is all over the map--nothing consistent at all. 175956041,"Over the years I have noticed a clear distinct pattern of almost actual behaviour to the nature of hearing voices, as though in real-time conversations with a person or persons. I would love to hear from anyone who has or can relate to these observations as in a relative model. In order to make it more digestible, I will list them as follows. 1) They (voices) use tactics to make you respond to them, as they(voices) are looking for a reaction or some kind of response, in order to form a type of repeatable trigger, the idea is to use anything they (voices) can use to get you to engage within the conversation, it could be flattery, humouring you, or mostly using invasive insults directed at you. What stands out is the need for you to feed them with your acknowledgement or attention. 2)The use of negative psychological tactics like Bait & Switch, procuring a trigger or anchoring you to a word or phrase in order to torture you with said stimulus. This is known as anchoring. 3) They at times when grouped 
together use sort of Phishing tricks in order to extract information, emotionally groom you or try to psychological blackmail you, once successfully phishing you for weakness within your character, also even more noticeable is that combined the 'voices' have the characteristics of a sociopath. They will constantly goad and taunt you 24/7 even when in the bathroom, it's like being tied to a sex offender as they will use you as a common street drug. 4) The rate of volume differentiates between loud group mobbing's, to the single whispering of one voice reminiscent of a game of charades, whereby you have to finish off the last word or guess what they referring to. 5) The use of uncommon language or unknown vocabulary within the context of what's said by the voices, you would have to lock up the intended reference or veiled suggestion. 6)They are more frequent at night time when trying to sleep, also this can be accompanied by a feeling of lightness of your head like if drunk the night before, as well as a moment
ary blue flash of light like a spotlight or street light shone directly at you, are about to nod off. You notice out the corner of your eye. 7)The voices can comment on real-time events and things that you are doing, which makes you think you're being covertly filmed or spied upon. via bugs or hidden camera's. Mimicking abusive trends like Molka. 8) It always responses back to your inner speech or what's termed as sub-vocalisation or silent speech. This offend gets confused with actual thoughts a person is having, as most real cognitive thoughts are non-vocal, like moving your arm or moving your head from side to side. 9) There seems to be an ear or side of your head that is more broadcast-able, with me it's my left Ear. 10) They stop the harassment/broadcast when you take the meds.( Rohypnol) 11) The experience can include momentary Tinnitus which sounds like a very tonal high pitched tone, like what you hear when attending a hearing test at Hospital Audio-gram machine. 12) Some times the voices are 24/7 and 
last for a number of years and at other times it's reduced to none at all. 13) By its nature it mimics trolling culture and Twitter storms, also Snap-chat witch hunts mobbing campaigns. 14) They 'Voices' try to turn you into their plaything or play cat & mouse with you, by use of power and control manipulation mind games. They want you to be a controlled victim or abuse plaything."

175956047,"* I apologize in advance if I come off as too much 'me me me' but I am attempting to share my own observations and experiences in order to possibly let others know how they are not alone * Many of my behavioral traits can be classified under the terms Borderline Personality Disorder, Depression and General Anxiety Disorder. Remember, we are referring to Behavioral actions. How we act/behave. I say this to remind myself as much as anyone else. Let's talk about the lack of self-identity I have. I can honestly say that I don't really know who I am. I'm a name that was assigned to me at birth. I have great struggles when it comes to what am I like?, what do people think of me? how do other people see me? I don't know but I'm thinking about it non-stop. along with the billion other things. I don't really have a strong sense of self. I am not very effective at boosting my own mood. I seek affection, approval and identity externally. That is the only way I can get it. What others think of me; what they sa
y to me; what they show me; and especially my constant repeating evaluation of what I THINK they think about me. It is so exhausting and spins the mind like the flywheel on a dragster going down the track. Relationships are so very challenging. I also will find myself in the sandbox with that awful schoolyard bully Paranoia and his sidekick _PERSON_. These two show up most of the time around my spouse. I know she is not doing anything other than trying to support me, love me and work with me to make the best life for our family. My mind is the worst toxin I could possibly imagine. It is debilitating, confusing, disorienting, makes me blind to reality, turns simple things into something so complex even modern day computers would respond with What?, and even if I am able to go to sleep when I'm having a severe struggle moment, it's right there like the worst hangover you can ever imagine when I wake up as if I never went to sleep. I will question anything and everything with my spouse some times when those two 
P&J show up and sit on my though process like a mac truck, even when I have every reason and all the proof in the world not to second-guess. Paranoia of not being good enough; not meeting expectations; disappointing the other person; disapproval by the other person; I fear disapproval and disappointment worse than death. I expect that I am not living up to their wants/needs/expectations and so I live in a state of constant guilt/shame/worry. I respond horribly to any comment/observation/point that does not shine rainbow and unicorns about my and will most of the time react in an angry, defensive-offensive manner and ride the runaway-train of emotion to ugly places. As my spouse says, I make a mountain out of a mole-hill, and let me tell you, Everest has nothing on my mountains. I have great difficulty appropriately communicating empathy/sympathy and really giving my spouse what she needs to truly feel listened to, heard and understood in the way she was intending. I can't get over that selfish emotion of, ""Y
eah I hear you but I want/need/feel...."" I often feel that my wants/needs/feelings are discounted, even though they may not be, and my reactions/words/actions, result in my spouse feeling discounted, and her feelings completely ignored. It's ugly. That's the ugly Aunt Selfishness. These demons extend beyond my spouse and I'm seeing more and more how several of them have been messing with me almost my whole life. I'm 46 years old and I was 'diagnosed' with BPD Borderline Personality Disorder last year, while at a partial hospitalization (daytime) program which I self-admitted to. I spent a lot of time at self-reflection and introspection. I actually utilized some of the aspects of AA and self discovery. I have my DBT workbook and I was in it about half an hour ago trying to shine up some of my tools. ** on a side note, DBT has some really great ideas and for some people it is their step-by-step instruction manual that they have on their nightstand and read a passage from every night. I'm honestly glad that wo
rks for you. For me, I'm more of a concepts, logic and practicality kind of guy. [ at least I like to think I am :) ] DBT is more of a supplement to my thought processes and logic paths, as well as organizational and decision tree tools. I expounded the jealousy/paranoia lens beyond just my spouse and looked at all of my relationships with family, friends, not-friends, acquaintances, significant others, FPs and where things went right as well as just as importantly where they went bad/wrong. I looked at where I had been stepped on, and painfully where I had stepped on others, directly or indirectly. I looked at trauma and issues that happened. I looked at my life through the lens of abandonment, even down to the smallest possible event. There were a lot of common threads that I could trace directly to one or more of the nine basic behavioral markers classified under Borderline Personality Disorder. I became aware of traits in my daughters as well as my parents and grandparents that were all hanging from the s
ame thread. Be honest with yourself. You are not BPD. BPD is an identifying label wrapped around behaviors that can really screw up our lives/relationships/minds. You may have some or all of those behavioral traits but that is not all you are. Reach out in as many directions as you can. Online Groups Online Chatrooms Online Forums Online MessageBoards Phone Numbers Google Hangout Meets Zoom meetings In-person 1-on-1 In-person small group In-person large group Don't limit yourself to 1 solution. There are many ways to hit a nail on the head and many of them will do just fine. I still struggle every day, sometimes every minute. I'm not done living yet. Even when I may loose hope that I have more to do and more to experience, I reach out in one way or another but I always make sure to be crystal clear on how much I'm hurting/struggling/suffering at that moment. Otherwise, I am just sabotaging myself and creating self-fulfilling prophesies, which I do way too much with BPD. There are not enough active/effective/b
eneficial resources. Not everyone heals the same way, just like not everyone learns or understands the same way. We need more. Keep active in these online resources. We need more 24/7 live resources."

175956069,"Sometimes there’s a bit of a set point....like I was stable at 165 as long as I was walking two miles a day and eating healthy....I was ok with that. 175956072,"I am updating since many of the original people who wrote on this post never followed up. I found this and it is literally the only place I have seen people that were having the same visual problems as I am. Mine got really bad, to the point that grocery store shelves and lines of text would kind of blur and then refocus constantly and look like they were moving. Since the worst of it I now have gotten a lot better and mostly only notice it on certain high contrast patterns and pictures. I never got an answer from my medical doctors and have been dealing with this for about 9 months. Computer screens are especially provoking. The good news is, if you stumble on this thread with the same issue like I did, you can probably expect some natural improvement although it may take awhile. Make sure you wear glasses if you need them, do your best to relax as much as you can and rest your eyes as much as possible. Good luck! I will update if the condition resolves on its own."

174342931,"Healthy Banana Peach Bread 1/2 cup applesauce 3/4 cup white sugar 1 tablespoon brown sugar 3-4 overripe bananas,peeled 1-2 ripe peaches, peeled, diced, or equivalent of canned 1/2 cup milk 2 eggs 1 tablespoon vanilla extract 2 cups all-purpose flour 1/2 cup chopped walnuts if u like 1 teaspoon baking soda 1 teaspoon salt Preheat to 350F. Grease bottom and side of loaf pan. In mixing bowl, ""cream"" the sugar, brown sugar, and applesauce. Place bananas, eggs, peaches, milk, and vanilla in another bowl and mix until smooth. Stir into applesauce mixture until well-incorporated. Mix flour, walnuts, salt, baking soda in a separate vessel, then, stir that into banana/peach mixture until flour mixture is just moistened. Pour batter into pan and bake for 45-55 minutes, using the toothpick or sharp knife methdod or whatever you use for doneness. Enjoy!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! I'm so glad I came back to PsychCentral and found you all. I live in a residential community for people with mental illness and it can feel surprisingly isolating because most of the people here don't want to get better or want to talk about their illnesses so we can support each other. Yesterday I mostly read (_NAME_), did some writing in my journal, then spent the evening with my family which is a regular thing for us to do on Wednesdays and Sundays. We have been going through the _PERSON_ movies in their chronological order--The Hobbit movies first, then The Lord of The Rings movies--and finished them last night. I also did some research on volunteering in my city and found that our local museum of fine arts needs help, so I think I'm going to look into volunteering there. 175956176,"_AT_MENTION_, That's so cool! _AT_MENTION_, Yup. Recalling peak moments as vividly as one can and, when the time is right, as far as possible recreating that chemical balance in the brain by combining certain activities, smells, air temperatures, qualities of light, etc. Although the sensations described below differ somewhat from the warmth of poshlost's experience, the passage still acknowledges an optimal mental state and the desire to sustain it: “There are moments in our lives, there are moments in a day, when we seem to see beyond the usual ? become clairvoyant. We reach then into reality. Such are the moments of our greatest happiness. Such are the moments of our greatest wisdom. It is in the nature of all people to have these experiences; but in our time and under the conditions of our lives, it is only a rare few who are able to continue in the experience and find expression for it.” ? _NAME_, The Art Spirit: Notes, Articles, Fragments of Letters and Talks to Students, Bearing on the C
oncept and Technique of Picture Making, the Study of Art In another thread (which I looked for but couldn't find), you wrote about feeding the pigeons (?) in Washington Square Park early one Sunday morning, and said that your fondest memories of your last relationship were always when you were physically away from your then-partner. I've always wanted to say that I think that that is true for most people. One of my mother's friends, _NAME_, a lady who was kind (without being patronizing) to us when we were poor, enjoyed a very happy marriage and raised kind children ? really good people. _NAME_ mentioned once to my mother that she thought the secret to her happy marriage might have been that she and her husband spent most of each day apart, in their own worlds, working on their own projects. Which leads me to suspect that, for neurotypicals as well as schizoids, the benefits of being 'with' someone are in fact the warmth of one's hours alone . That, in fact, actual time with a partner is best appreciated when 
kept to a minimum. I sent the following to my schizoid friend: '""We should make a minimum of gestures, pronounce a minimum of words, even see each other as seldom as possible, if that would prolong things.We don't know how much of everything we have ahead of us so we have to take the greatest precautions not to destroy the beauty of what we have. Everything exists in limited quantity ? especially happiness. If a love is to come into being, it is all written down somewhere, and also its duration and content. If you could arrive at a complete intensity the first day, it would be ended the first day. And so if it's something you want so much that you'd like to have it prolonged in time, you must be extremely careful not to make the slightest excessive demand that might prevent it from developing to the greatest extent over the longest period."" . . . Until then he had been, for me, the great painter that everyone knew about and admired, a very intelligent, witty man but impersonal. From then on he became a pers
on. Until then he had aroused my interest and engaged my mind. Now my emotions and affections were involved. I had not thought before then that I could ever love him. Now I knew it could be no other way. He was obviously capable of sidestepping all stereotyped formulas in his human relations just as completely as in his art. One recognizes the stereotypes even if one has not experienced them all. He took command of the situation by stopping the intellectual game, sidestepping the erotic one, and putting our relationship on the only basis possible in order to be significant for him and ? as I even then realized ? for me as well.' ? _PERSON_, Life with Picasso"
175956177,"This is a first. You are the only schizoid I've seen admit to ever having operated a vehicle (legitimately). Is there an inverse relationship between the two? I no longer smoke weed but seldom have vivid dreams. Same with my schizoid friend who doesn't think he dreams at all. If he does he can't recall them. Talk about a ripoff. This might be the single best way to identify schizoids in the wild. That's not so unusual. We have our ringer and voice volume zeroed-out ALL the time. My cell phone is always off, and I check email once a day if that. Seriously (pitifully?), I find bowling compelling, riveting, and suspenseful And the deal with never actually doing the thing which thrills one the most is not exclusive to schizoids. Whatever deluxe combo platter of undiagnosed mental illnesses I have manifests itself in that way too, among others. This might be common to many mental illnesses. Petty objections aside, you've actually built a strong case. I seem to recall several observations here and there 
that certain characters from popular entertainment (live-action and animated) exhibit schizoid traits. Perhaps catering to a groundswell of demand? Could it be. Could it just be, that there are actually a ton of schizoids about, feigning affection, mimicking normalcy? Such that our collective idea of 'normalcy' is increasingly, if not entirely, artificial? Arguably, the percentage of neglectful, self-absorbed, superficial, materialistic, impatient, and entitled parents has been increasing since the TV age."

We all try to recover in our own time. As much as caregivers try, it’s only the struggling who can really make that ultimate choice."

175956210,"I hope they give you the Remeron and that it works for you! I know how horrible insomnia is from experience! If you do take the Remeron, they recommend you are in bed or headed to bed when you take it. It can kick in somewhat quickly. Yeah, you need something more than meditation/calming exercises right now! Oh, and also, I only need to take half of a 15 mg Remeron for it to knock me out (so 7.5 mg). One possible side effect when you first start it is bad nightmares. That did happen to me the first time I took it many years ago but it did not happen to me when I took it earlier this year. It only lasted a couple nights the first time though. Just a heads up."

175956212,"Hi there. I’ve been meaning to respond to this because I also have bipolar. It can be debilitating for sure, but I do think there’s hope for some amount of recovery, though it takes hard work and a lot of support. I don’t know the situation as well as you do, so I can’t say whether your fiancé would be willing or able to put that work in right now to find the resources and supports he needs. I think what’s important here is that you are not responsible for his mental health, he is. So you need to do what’s best for you in the long term. That being said, there are some resources available that he may be interested in. The Depression and Bipolar Support Alliance has support groups (though they may be meeting online right now because of the virus). If you go to their website, you can put in your zip code and see what they have near you. They also have this thing called the Wellness Wheel that you can fill out periodically to track your mental health progress. I know of someone that this h
as helped a lot. I wish the best for both of you and hope that you can make peace with whatever decision you make. It’s a hard situation to be in ??"

174343043,"Bavarian Pineapple Cream 1 cup pinapple juice 1/4 tsp. salt 1 cup whipping cream 1 cup crushed pineapple 2 tsp cold water 1 tsp lemon juice 1 envelope gelatin 1/2 cup sugar Heat the pineapple juice. Soften the gelatin in the cold water then stir into hot pineapple juice. Add sugar, salt, and lemon juice, then the crushed pineapple. Cool and stir until the mixture is partially set. Beat the gelatin mixture until foamy. Beat the cream into stiff peaks and fold into the gelatin mixture. Pour into a mold and set."

175956242,"The first psychiatric medication that I was put on was Zoloft. But I wasn't on it long enough for it to cause me weight gain. However, psychiatric medications that I was put on after going off the Zoloft caused me to gain weight rather quickly back in 2000. But I actually liked gaining the weight. I was too skinny before going on meds, and I hated it. I disliked not being able put on weight. After gaining over eighty pounds years ago, I have lost most of the weight since then. However, I don't want to lose all of the weight and end up looking underweight once again."

175956253,"It depends on the nature of the relationship. You don't have to tell at all, if you don't want to do so. But, if you want to live together or have a more serious relationship, then may be, you should confide in the person. I think if you are dating someone who has no clue about mental illness, that person could be in for a shock. But, if the person is also mentally ill, then confiding in that person should not be an issue. Eventually, if you do become serious, then confiding may be important. When should you confide in that person? Well, there is no good time, but. may be, you should wait until that person confides in you about that person's health issues. As a result, it all depends on what you are seeking from that person."
175956254,"With the recent horrific events, there have been some very stigmatizing thoughts and words expressed about those of us with mental illness and the ‘risk’ we pose. We do not pose a risk to others Firstly I want to say how incredibly sorry I am to the families, friends and loved ones of those who have been hurt or killed in these events, I cannot imagine what they are going through and my thoughts are truly with all who have been impacted. This article is not about the people who have spoken out and said that we with mental illness are to be feared and locked away, which is why I will not include their exact statements or mention their names; it’s about us, the mental health community, and us raising our voices to say that this is NOT acceptable. We are NOT violent, we are NOT dangerous, we are NOT a risk to others. Do not tar everyone with mental illness with the same brush While we do not know the mental health history of the people who committed these crimes, there is a chance that they do h
ave a mental illness, however even if this is the case, this does not mean that all people with mental illnesses are a risk to others; just the same way as someone who commits a crime and does not have a mental illness, does not therefore mean that all people out there without mental illnesses are a risk to others. Everybody is individual and we cannot tar everyone with the same brush. https://blogs.psychcentral.com/bipolar-journey/2019/08/having-a-mental-illness-does-not-make-us-a-risk-to-others/"

175956267,"Andwes, Of course this is a huge anxiety inducing adjustment for you! I can't imagine how it wouldn't affect you, on many levels. First of all moving, period, is stressful. 175956275,"For me it was very difficult. The issue was that I couldn't understand not being right, which may sound odd, but I'd never considered the fact that my PoV might be the one that was inaccurate. This may apply to everyone, but for me it was worse, because my behaviour was so damaging to those around me. Bear in mind that I'd been told that I was wrong since I was a kid and that has never really stopped, so my attachment to being right was fundamentally identifying. Now, I tend to do the opposite. I almost crave being wrong because I now know that it's not going to be destroying to me and I find myself becoming addicted to another point of view. I guess it was never really about ""being"" right; it was about not being able to accept the fact that maybe my self-perception was inaccurate. There's a lot of fallout to it. Having to accept, albeit it theoretically, that I'm to blame for much of the stuff I've been accused of doesn't give me much justification space, but it does make me feel better. I prefe
r to think that I'm to blame for others' misery, as it doesn't feel unjust anymore. Nice quote."

This is what the site said about uncertainty and it relates to me; ""Seeking excessive reassurance from others: This might be asking friends or family their opinion on a decision that you have to make List-making: As a way of eliminating uncertainty, some people will make long and detailed “to do” lists, sometimes several lists every day Double checking: For example, calling loved ones repeatedly to “make sure” that they are okay, or re-reading emails several times to check that they are perfect and that there are no spelling mistakes Refusing to delegate tasks to others: Many people who are intolerant of uncertainty will not allow a
nyone either at work or at home to do certain tasks; this is because they cannot be “sure” that it will be done correctly unless they do it Procrastination/avoidance: Because being uncertain can cause anxiety, some people simply procrastinate or avoid people, places or situations. If you do not do something, then you don’t have to feel uncertain about it Distraction: Many people who are intolerant of uncertainty keep themselves “busy” most of the day, that way, they don’t have the time to think about all the uncertainty in life"""

175956403,"asiangal555: You said that you took Mirtazapine anti-depressant for anxiety. I didn’t fully realize that most medicines prescribed for anxiety are anti-depressants. about the anti-depressant you’re taking, Mirtazapine, net says it does help with anxiety also. I as a bipolar also take Mirtazapine, for the depressed side of my bipolar, while I take Lithium stabilizer to keep the anti-depressant from getting my mania going, or from causing panic attacks. From reading the net, it seems there is one (main) long term medicine (not short term like Zanax) used to treat anxiety. It's called Burspar, now also called Buspirone. The website californiahighlandvistas.com says: “GoodRx writes that health care providers can prescribe buspirone in addition to an antidepressant to treat generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). That antidepressant can be either a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) or a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). It has been found that buspirone can help enhance th
e effects of an antidepressant drug.” Again, it says, “It has been found that Buspirone (Buspar) can help enhance the effects of an antidepressant drug.” So, if you’re still anxious from taking just the Mirtazapine, maybe you can ask your doctor about what he or she thinks about your taking Buspar along with the Mirtazapine “to enhance the effects of the antidepressant drug.” It also says above, ""That antidepressant can be either a selective serotonin reuptake inhibitor (SSRI) or a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI). It has been found that buspirone can help enhance the effects of an antidepressant drug.” The net also says Mirtazapine antidepressant is not in those classes (SNRI or SSRI), so you will probably need to ask your doctor if you'll need to change your antidepressant. I find this data by typing into the search engine: ""Mirtazapine for anxiety"" and ""anti-anxiety medicine"" and ""Buspar for anxiety."" You might want to look at some of those topics, also."

175956416,"I'm a weedhead, so yeah, I have issues. I don't smoke nearly as much as I used to, but so what. Technically I'm a drug addict. Marijuana can make me paranoid in high doses, but I don't smoke up like that anymore. It definitely makes me more insular and withdrawn, but I was introverted long before I started smoking. A simple trip to the grocery store can be thwarted by getting even a little bit high, but if I have some social obligation I can't get out of, smoking will make it more bearable. If I'm already out, it can increase my sociability, but that's not necessarily a good thing because it can also make me stupid and abstract to the point where nobody knows what the hell I'm talking about. For me, it crushes anxiety better than alcohol or benzos. So there's that."
175956417,"Thanks folks. I was given Wellbutrin and lithium carbonate by my doc. He also gave me a referral to physical therapy because I included that I formerly could improve symptoms with running, but not since a running injury. It took em a few weeks but I got in to see a psychiatry office. I saw a nurse but she was smart. She gave me lamictal instead of lithium to control my irritability and anger feelings. The physical therapy is covered except for co pay which is cool. They happen to include massage and “dry needling” which is acupuncture but on the muscles rather than meridians. I’m so glad I got this looked into before coronavirus, and we are all home. Currently the kids are watching tv after a while melt down over practicing piano. My kids are adverse to even slightest discomfort (like playing legos alone or playing a piano song one more time). At least I am able to weather this with a calmer attitude.
